stage.#text: Scene.--Near Cyrene, in ; not far from the sea-shore, and before the cottage of DMONES and the Temple of Venus, which has, probably, a small court before it, surrounded with a low wall.

p.#text: DMONES, an aged Athenian, having lost his property, goes to live in retirement near the sea-shore of , in the vicinity of the Temple of Venus. It so happens that Labrax, a Procurer, makes purchase of two damsels, Palstra and Ampelisca, and comes to reside at . Plesidippus, a young Athenian, sees Palstra there, and falls in love with her; and making an arrangement with the Procurer, gives him a sum in part payment for her, on which occasion, Labrax invites him to a sacrifice in the Temple of Venus. A Sicilian guest of his, however, named Charmides, persuades him to carry the young women over to , where he is sure to make a greater profit by them. On this, the Procurer, accompanied by his guest, sets sail with them. A tempest arises, and they are shipwrecked. The young women escape in a boat, and arriving ashore, are hospitably received by the Priestess of Venus. Labrax and Charmides also escape, and on discovering where the women are, the former attempts to drag them by force from the Temple. On this they are protected by Dmones and Plesidippus, who, through Trachalio, finds out where they are. In the wreck a wallet has been lost, which belongs to Labrax, and in which is a casket enclosing some trinkets belonging to Palstra. Gripus, a servant of Dmones, draws this up with the rope attached to his net; and by means of these trinkets it is discovered that Palstra is the daughter of Dmones, whom he had lost in her infancy; on which she is given in marriage to Plesidippus by her father, who becomes reconciled to Labrax.

note.#text: [Supposed to have been written by Priscian the Grammarian.]

p.#text: A FISHERMAN draws a wallet out of the sea in his net (), in which () are the trinkets of his master's daughter, who, having been stolen, had come into the possession of a Procurer as her owner (). She (), having suffered shipwreck (), without knowing it comes under the protection of her own father; she is recognized, and is married to her () lover Plesidippus.

note.title: Tempest
note.#text: :  This is a star near the tail of the Great Bear, whose rising and setting was supposed to be productive of great tempests. The name is derived from its situation, from the Greek words  and  "the Bear's tail." It rises in the beginning of October. Pliny mentions it as rising on the 12th, and Columella on the 5th of that month.   We may here remark, that the Play is called "the Fisherman's Rope" in consequence of the important part which, towards the close, the rope acts in bringing the wallet to shore in the net. The scenery of this Play must have been much more picturesque than that of those of Plautus in general. At the end of the stage is a prospect of the sea, interspersed with rocks in the distance, while others project upon the front of the stage. The City of  is also seen in the distance; while nearer to the Audience is the Temple of Venus, with an altar in front of it; and adjoining the Temple is the cottage of Dmones. Some other cottages are also seen at a distance. If the comparison may be made, it bears some slight resemblance to the  of Shakspeare.

p.#text: WITH him who sways all nations, seas, and lands, I am a fellow-citizen in the realms of the Gods. I am, as you see, a bright and shining star, a Constellation that ever in its season rises here on earth and in the heavens. Arcturus is my name. By night, I am glittering in the heavens and amid the Gods, passing among mortals in the day. Other Constellations, too, descend from the heavens upon the earth; Jove, who is the ruler of Gods and men--he disperses us here in various directions among the nations, to observe the actions, manners, piety, and faith of men, just as the means of each avail him. Those who commence villanous suits at law upon false testimony, and those who, in court, upon false oath deny a debt, their names written down, do we return to Jove. Each day does he learn who here is calling for vengeance. Whatever wicked men seek here to gain their cause through perjury, who succeed before the judge in their unjust demands, the same case adjudged does he judge over again, and he fines them in a penalty much greater than the results of the judgment they have gained. The good men written down on other tablets does he keep. And still these wicked persons entertain a notion of theirs, that they are able to appease  with gifts, with sacrifice; both their labour and their cost they lose. This, for this reason, is so, because no petition of the perjured is acceptable to Him. If any person that is supplicating the Deities is pious, he will more easily procure pardon for himself than he that is wicked. Therefore I do advise you this, you who are good and who pass your lives in piety and in virtue--still persevere, that one day you may rejoice that so you did. Now, the reason for which I've come hither, I will disclose to you. First, then, Diphilus has willed the name of this city to be . There  dwells Dmones, in the country and in a cottage very close adjoining to the sea, an old gentleman who has come hither in exile from , no unworthy man. And still, not for his bad deserts has he left his country, but while he was aiding others, meanwhile himself he embarrassed: a property honorably acquired he lost by his kindly ways. Long since, his daughter, then a little child, was lost; a most villanous fellow bought her of the thief, and this Procurer brought the maiden hither to . A certain Athenian youth, a citizen of this city, beheld her as she was going home from the music-school. He begins to love her; to the Procurer he comes; he purchases the damsel for himself at the price of thirty min, and gives him earnest, and binds the Procurer with an oath. This Procurer, just as befitted him, did not value at one straw his word, or what, on oath, he had said to the young man. He had a guest, a fit match for himself, an old man of , a rascal from , a traitor to his native city; this fellow began to extol the beauty of that maiden, and of the other damsels, too, that were belonging to him. On this he began to persuade the Procurer to go together with himself to ; he said that there the men were given to pleasure; that there he might be enabled to become a wealthy man; that there was the greatest profit from courtesans. He prevails. A ship is hired by stealth. Whatever he has, by night the Procurer carries it on board ship from his house; the young man who purchased the damsel of him he has told that he is desirous of performing a vow to Venus. This is the Temple of Venus, here , and here, for that reason, has he invited the youth hither to a breakfast. From there at once did he embark on board ship, and he carried off the courtesans. Some other persons informed the young man what things were going on, how that the Procurer had departed. When the young man came to the harbour, their ship had got a great way out to sea. When I beheld how that the maiden was being carried off, I brought at the same instant both relief to her and destruction to the Procurer; the storm I rebuked, and the waves of the sea I aroused. For the most violent Constellation of them all am 1, Arcturus; turbulent I am when rising, when I set, more turbulent still. Now, cast ashore there, both the Procurer and his guest are sitting upon a rock; their ship is dashed to pieces. But this maiden, and another as well, her attendant, affrighted, have leaped from the ship into a boat. At this moment the waves are bringing them from the rocks to land, to the cottage of this old man, who is living here in exile, whose roof and tiles the storm has stript off. And this is his servant who is coming out of doors. The youth will be here just now, and you shall see him, who purchased the maiden of the Procurer. Now, fare ye well, and may your foes distrust themselves.

div2.stage: Enter SCEPARNIO, with a spade on his shoulder.

note.#text: :  He alludes to a Tragedy of Euripides so named, where a dreadful storm was so accurately represented that at length the Play became a proverbial expression for tempestuous weather. Madame Dacier observes, that it was not strange for Sceparnio to mention this, as he might often have seen it represented at  upon the stage. This notion is somewhat far-fetched, as it is not likely that Plautns troubled himself about such a fine point, or that the Audience was gifted with any such nicety of perception as to note his accuracy, even if he had. It has been suggested, and not at all improbably, that Plautus borrowed the Scene of the thunder and lightning in his Amphitryon from this Play of Euripides.

p.#text: . O ye immortal Gods, what a dreadful tempest has Neptune sent us this last night! The storm has unroofed the cottage. What need of words is there? It was no storm, but what Alcmena met with in Euripides; it has so knocked all the tiles from off the roof; more light has it given us, and has added to our windows.

div2.stage: Enter PLESIDIPPUS, at a distance, talking with three CITIZENS.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: I have both withdrawn you from your avocations, and that has not succeeded on account of which I've brought you; I could not catch the Procurer down at the harbour. But I have been unwilling to abandon all hope by reason of my remissness; on that account, my friends, have I the longer detained you. Now hither to the Temple of Venus am I come to see, where he was saying that he was about to perform a sacrifice.

stage: aloud to himself, at a distance
p.#text: . If I am wise, I shall be getting ready this clay that is awaiting me.
. Some one, I know not who, is speaking near to me.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: Hallo! Sceparnio!

sp.speaker: SCEPARNIO
sp.p: Who's calling me by name?

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: He who paid his money for you.

p.#text: . As though you would say, Dmones, that I am your slave.

note.#text: :  He probably means clay for the purpose of drying and making tiles with it.

p.#text: There's occasion for plenty of clay, therefore dig up plenty of earth. I find that the whole of my cottage must be covered; for now it's shining through it, more full of holes than a sieve.
. Health to you, good father, and to both of you, indeed. DM. Health to you.

p.stage: to PLESIDIPPUS, who is muffled up in a coat
p.#text: . But whether are you male or female, who are calling him father?

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: Why really, I'm a man.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: Then, man, go seek a father elsewhere. I once had an only daughter, that only one I lost. Of the male sex I never had a child.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: But the Gods will give----

p.#text: . A heavy mischance to you indeed, i' faith, whoever you are, who are occupying us, already occupied, with your prating.
. Pray are you dwelling there?

sp.speaker: SCEPARNIO
sp.p: Why do you ask that? Are you reconnoitring the place for you to come and rob there?

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: It befits a slave to be right rich in his savings, whom, in the presence of his master, the conversation cannot escape, or who is to speak rudely to a free man.

sp.speaker: SCEPARNIO
sp.p: And it befits a man to be shameless and impudent, for him to whom there's nothing owing, of his own accord to come to the house of another person annoying people.

p.#text: Sceparnio, hold your tongue.  What do you want, young man?

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: A mishap to that fellow, who is in a hurry to be the first to speak when his master's present. But, unless it's troublesome, I wish to make enquiry of you in a few words.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: My attention shall be given you, even though in the midst of business.

note.#text: :  From this we learn that the cottage of Dmones was covered with a kind of thatch. This and l. 18 of the Miles Gloriosus are probably the earliest instances in which thatched roofs are mentioned.

p.#text: . Rather, be off with you to the marsh, and cut down some reeds, with which we may cover the cottage, while it is fine weather.
Hold your tongue. Do you tell me  if you have need of anything.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: Inform me on what I ask you; whether you have seen here any frizzle-headed fellow, with grey hair, a worthless, perjured, fawning knave.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: Full many a one; for by reason of fellows of that stamp am I living in misery.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: Him, I mean, who brought with him to the Temple of Venus here two young women, and who was to make preparations for himself to perform a sacrifice either to-day or yesterday.

note.#text: :  "Aula extaris." Literally, "a pot for holding the entrails" of the animals sacrificed.

p.#text: By my faith, young man, for these very many days past I haven't seen any one sacrificing there; and yet it can't be unknown to me if any one does sacrifice there. They are always asking here for water, or for fire, or for vessels, or for a knife, or for a spit, or for a pot for cooking, or something or other. What need is there of words? I procured my vessels and my well, for the use of Venus, and not my own. There has now been a cessation of it for these many days past.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: According to the words you utter, you tell me I'm undone.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: Really, so far as I'm concerned, i' faith, you may be safe and sound.

note.#text: :  It was the custom of Parasites to prowl about the Temples, for the purpose of joining in the feasts which sometimes took place at the conclusion of the sacrifice.

p.#text: . Hark you, you that are roaming about Temples for the sake of your stomach, 'twere better for you to order a breakfast to be got ready at home. Perhaps you've been invited here to breakfast. He that invited you, hasn't he come at all?

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: 'Tis the fact.

p.#text: There's no risk then in your betaking yourself hence home without your breakfast. It's better for you to be a waiter upon  than upon Venus; the latter attends to love,  attends to wheat.
. This fellow has been making sport of me in a digraceful manner.
. O ye immortal Gods, Sceparnio, what means those people near the sea-shore?

note.#text: :  "Prandium propter viam." Thornton has the following Note here: "This is a sorry joke, even for Sceparnio, on so serious and melancholy an occasion, and cannot be well expressed in our tongue. When the ancients were about to undertake any voyage, they used to make a sacrifice to  before they set off, which was for that reason called 'propter viam;' and the custom was to burn all they didn't eat. Wherefore Sceparnio says 'laverunt,' which signifies 'they have consumed their all' as well as they have bathed.' alluding to the ship being lost."

p.#text: According to my notion, they've been invited to a parting breakfast.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: SCEPARNIO
sp.p: Why, because, after dinner, I fancy, they yesterday washed themselves clean; their ship has gone to pieces out at sea.

p.#text: . Such is the fact.

sp.speaker: SCEPARNIO
sp.p: But, i' faith, on dry land our cottage and tiles have done the same.

p.#text: Oh dear! what unfortunate creatures you are;  how the shipwrecked people are swimming.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: Prithee, where are these people?

p.#text: . This way, to the right; don't you see them near the shore?
. I see them;  follow me. I only wish it may be he that I'm seeking, that most accursed fellow.  Fare you well.

p.stage: (Exeunt PLESIDIPPUS and FRIENDS.  SCEPARNIO looks out towards the sea.)

note.#text: :  This was one of the names of Melicerta. or Portunus, the son of Athamas and Ino. Athamas being about to slay him and Ino, they leaped into the sea, where they became sea Divinities.

p.#text: If you hadn't put us in mind, we should have thought of that ourselves. . But, O Palmon, hallowed associate of Neptune, who art said to be the partner of Hercules, what shocking thing do I see?

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: What do you see?

p.#text: I see two young women sitting in a boat alone. How the poor things are being tossed about That's good, that's good, well done. The surge is driving the boat away from the rock towards the shore. Not a pilot could have ever done it better. I don't think that I ever saw billows more huge. They are saved, if they can escape those waves. Now, now's the danger; it has sent one overboard! See you that one whom the waves have thrown out of the boat? Still, she's in a shallow place; she'll easily wade through it now. O capital! now she's safe; she has escaped from the water; she's now on shore. But that other one has now sprung towards the land from the boat--from her alarm she has fallen into the waves upon her knees. She has got up again; if she takes this direction, the matter's safe;  but she has taken to the right, to utter destruction. Ah, she will be wandering all the day----

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: What signifies that to you?

sp.speaker: SCEPARNIO
sp.p: If she should fall down from that rock towards which she is wending her way, she'll be putting a period to her wandering.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: If you are about to dine this evening at their expense, I think you may then be concerned for them, Sceparnio; if you are going to eat at my house, I wish your services to be devoted to myself.

sp.speaker: SCEPARNIO
sp.p: You ask what's good and proper.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: Then follow me this way.

note.#text: :  The Scene of the wreck, previously described by Sceparnio, was probably not visible to the Audience, but was depicted by him while directing his view towards the side. of the stage.

p.#text: I follow.

div2.stage: Enter PALSTRA, at a distance, with her clothes torn and drenched.

stage: She advances forward, and rests on one side against the cliff.

note.#text: :  Exactly the same sentiment occurs to 's hero, Robinson Crusoe, when he visits the Spanish ship wrecked off his island: "I cannot explain by any possible energy of words what a strange longing or hankering of desires I felt in my soul upon this sight, breaking out sometimes thus, 'O that there had been but one or two, nay, or but one soul saved out of this ship, to have escaped to me, that I might have had one companion, one fellow-creature to have spoken to me and to have conversed with!"
:  She is unable to see the Temple of  and the house of Dmones, by reason of the high crags among which she is wandering, some of which are represented in the front of the stage.

p.#text: . By heavens, the mishaps of mortals are spoken of as much less bitter than * * * * * * * the sharp pangs that are inflicted in the experience of them * * * * Has this then pleased the Deity, that I, clad in this guise, should, in my terror, be cast upon a spot unknown? Shall I then declare that I have been born to this wretched lot? Do I receive this meed in return for my exemplary piety? For to me it would not prove a hardship to endure this laborious lot, if I had conducted myself undutifully towards my parents or the Gods; but if studiously I have exerted myself to beware of that, then, unduly and unjustly, Deities, you send upon me this. For what henceforth shall the glaringly impious receive, if after this fashion you pay honor to the guiltless? But if I knew that I or my parents had done anything wicked, now should I have grieved the less. But the wickedness of this master of mine is pressing hard upon me, his impiety is causing my woes; everything has he lost in the sea; these are the remains  of his property. Even she, who was carried together with me in the boat, was washed out by the violence of the waves; I am now alone. If she at least had been saved for me, through her aid my affliction here would have been lighter to me. Now, what hope or aid or what counsel shall I receive, a spot so lonesome here have I lighted upon alone? Here are the rocks, here roars the sea, and not one individual comes across my path. This dress that I am clothed in forms all my riches quite entirely; nor know I with what food or roof I am to be provided. What hope have I through which to desire to live? Neither am I acquainted with the place, nor was I ever here before. At least I could have wished for some one who would point out to me either a road or a path from these spots; so much am I now at a loss for advice whether to go this way or that; neither, indeed, do I see anywhere near here a cultivated spot. Cold, distraction, and alarm, have taken possession of all my limbs. My parents, you know not of this, that I am now thus wretched; I that was born a woman entirely free, was so to no purpose. Am I at all the less in servitude now, than if I had been born a slave? And never in any way has it been a profit to those who for their own sakes reared me up.

div2.stage: Enter AMPELISCA, at a distance, on the other side of the stage, in a similar condition.

p.#text: . What is there better for me, what more to my advantage, than to shut out life from my body? So wretched am I in my existence, and so many deadening cares are there in my breast; so despicable is my lot; I care not for my life; I have lost the hope with which I used to comfort myself. All places have I now rambled about, and through each covert spot have I crawled along, to seek my fellow-slave with voice, eyes, ears, that I might trace her out. And still I find her nowhere, nor have I yet determined whither to go, nor where to seek her, nor, in the meantime, do I find any person here to give me an answer, of whom I might make enquiry. No place, too, is there on earth more solitary than are these spots and this locality. And yet, if she lives, never while I exist will I cease before I discover her alive.
. Whose voice is it that sounds close by me here?
. I am alarmed. Who's speaking near me?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRA
sp.p: Prithee, kind Hope, do come to my aid.

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA
sp.p: It's a woman: a woman's voice reaches my ears. Will you not rescue wretched me from this alarm?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRA
sp.p: Surely a woman's voice reached my ears. Prithee is it Ampelisca?

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA
sp.p: Is it you, Palstra, that I hear?

p.#text: But why don't I call her by her own name, that she may hear me?  Ampelisca!

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA
sp.p: Ha! who's that?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRA
sp.p: 'Tis I.

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA
sp.p: Is it Palstra?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRA
sp.p: It is.

note.#text: :  It must be remembered that they are still separated by the crags upon the stage, though they are both visible to the Audience.

p.#text: Tell me where you are.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRA
sp.p: Troth, I'm now in the midst of a multitude of woes.

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA
sp.p: I am your partner; and no less is my own share than yours. But I long to see you.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRA
sp.p: In that wish you are my rival.

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA
sp.p: Let's follow our voices with our steps; where are you?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRA
sp.p: See, here am I. Step onward towards me, and come straight on to meet me.

p.stage: They meet in front of the stage.
p.#text: I'm doing so with care.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRA
sp.p: Give me your hand.

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA
sp.p: Take it.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRA
sp.p: Are you still alive Prithee, tell me.

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA

p.#text: You, indeed, make me now wish to live, since I'm empowered to touch you. How hardly can I persuade myself of this, that I am holding you. Prithee, do embrace me , my only hope; how you are now easing me of all my woes.

p: PAL. You are beforehand with me in using expressions which belong to me. Now it befits us to be going hence.

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA
sp.p: Prithee, whither shall we go?

p.#text: Let's keep along this sea-shore.  AMP. Wherever you please, I'll follow.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRA
sp.p: Shall we go along thus with our wet clothing?

p.#text: That which exists, the same must of necessity be borne.  But, pray, what's this?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRA
sp.p: What is it?

p.#text: Prithee, don't you see this Temple?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRA
sp.p: Where is it?

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA
sp.p: On the right hand.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRA
sp.p: I seem to be looking at a place becoming the Divinities.

p.stage: They advance towards the Temple, and kneel down before it.
p.#text: There must be people not far hence; it is so delightful a spot. Whoever the God is, I pray him to relieve us from these troubles, and to succour us females, wretched, helpless, and in distress.

stage.#text: Enter PTOLEMOCRATIA, the Priestess, from the Temple of .

sp.speaker: PTOLEMOCRATIA
sp.p: Who are these, that in their prayers are soliciting aid from my Patroness? For the voice of suppliants has brought me hither out of doors. They pay suit to a kind and compliant Goddess and a Patroness that makes no difficulties, and one who is very benevolent.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRA
sp.p: Mother, we bid you hail.

sp.speaker: PTOLEMOCRATIA
sp.p: Maidens, hail to you. But, prithee, whence am I to say that you are hither come with your wet garments, thus wofully arrayed?

p.#text: Just now, we came from a place there , not a great way from this spot; but it is a great way off from here, whence we have been brought hither.

note.#text: :  Homer calls ships "horses of the sea."

p.#text: Have you been borne, do you mean, by a ship, the wooden steed, over the azure paths?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRA
sp.p: Even so.

p.#text: Then it were more fitting that you should have come arrayed in white and provided with victims; it isn't the practice for people to come to this Temple in that fashion.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRA
sp.p: Prithee, whence would you have us, who have been both cast away at sea, to be bringing victims hither? Now, in want of assistance, do we embrace your knees, we who are of hopes undefined in places unknown, that you may receive us under your roof and shelter us, and that you will pity the miseries of us both, who have neither any place of refuge nor hope at hand, nor have anything whatever of our own beyond that which you see.

p.#text: Give me your hands, arise, both of you, from off your knees; no one among women is more compassionate than I.  But, maidens, my circumstances are poor and limited; with difficulty I support my own existence;  I serve for my maintenance.
Prithee, is this a Temple of ?

sp.speaker: PTOLEMOCRATIA
sp.p: I will admit it; I am styled the Priestess of this Temple. But whatever it is, it shall be done by me with a hearty welcome, so far as my means shall suffice. Come with me this way.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRA
sp.p: Kindly and attentively, mother, do you show your attentions to us.

p.#text: So I ought to do.

div2.stage: Ente some FISHERMEN, with lines and nets.

note.#text: :  "Balanos." It is not known what shellfish the "balani" really were.
:  It is not known what kind of fish the "plagusia" was.

: -- "Salsi lautique pure."  says, "Madame Dacier supposes that a joke is intended here, from the equivocal meaning of the words, which might mean that they had been entertained with high-seasoned cates, or that they had been washed and cleansed with salt water.  'Salsi,' says she, because sea-water is salt; 'pure,' because sea-water washed away all impurities."

p.stage: They advance towards the door of the Temple.
p.#text: Persons who are poor live wretchedly in every way, especially those who have no calling and have learned no art. Of necessity must that be deemed enough, whatever they have at home. From our garb, then, you pretty well understand how wealthy we are. These hooks and these rods here are as good to us as a calling and as our clothing. Each day from the city do we come out hither to the sea to seek for forage. Instead of exertion in the wrestling-school and the place for exercise, we have this: sea-urchins, rock-mussels, oysters, limpets, cockles, sea-nettles, sea-mussels and spotted crabs, we catch. After that, we commence our fishing with the hook and among the rocks, and thus we take our food from out of the sea. If success does not befall us, and not any fish is taken, soaked in salt water and thoroughly drenched, we quietly betake ourselves home, and without dinner go to sleep. And since the sea is now in waves so boisterous, no hopes have we; unless we take some cockles, without a doubt we've had our dinners. Now let's adore good  here, that she may kindly befriend us to-day.

div2.stage: Enter TRACHALIO, at a distance, in haste.

note.#text: :  "Conchit -- hamist." These words are supposed to have been coined by Plautus for the occasion.

:   has this Note here: "There is an humour in the original which could not be preserved in our language. Instead of asking the fishermen 'Ut valetis? which was the common phrase of salutation, Trachalio addresses them in the opposite term, 'Ut peritis?'--prooably un allusion to their perilous calling."

p.#text: . I've carefully given all attention that I mightn't pass my master anywhere; for when some time since he went out of the house, he said that he was going to the harbour, and he ordered me to come here to meet him at the Temple of . But see, opportunely do I espy some people standing here of whom I may enquire; I'll accost them.  Save you, thieves of the sea, shellfish-gatherers and hook-fishers, hungry race of men, how fare ye? How perish apace?

sp.speaker: FISHERMEN of Cyrene.
sp.p: Just as befits a fisherman with hunger, thirst, and expectation.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Have you seen to-day, while you've been standing here, any young man, of courageous aspect, ruddy, stout, of genteel appearance, come by this way, who was taking with him three men in scarfs, with swords?

sp.speaker: FISHERMEN of Cyrene.
sp.p: We know of no one coming this way of that appearance which you mention.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Have you seen any old fellow, bald on the forehead and snub-nosed, of big stature, pot-bellied, with eyebrows awry, a narrow forehead, a knave, the scorn of Gods and men, a scoundrel, one full of vile dishonesty and of iniquity, who had along with him two very pretty-looking young women?

p.#text: One who has been born with qualities and endowments of that sort, 'twere really fitter for him to resort to the executioner than to the Temple of .

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: But tell me if you have seen him.

sp.speaker: FISHERMEN of Cyrene.
sp.p: Really, no one has passed this way. Fare you well.

p.#text: Fare ye well.

. I thought so; it has come to pass as I suspected; my master has been deceived; the cursed Procurer has taken himself off to distant lands. He has embarked on board ship, and carried the women away; I'm a wizard. He invited my master here to breakfast, as well, this very spawn of wickedness. Now what is better for me than to wait here in this spot until my master comes? At the same time, if this Priestess of  knows anything more, if I see her, I'll make enquiries; she'll give me the information.

div2.stage: Enter AMPELISCA, from the Temple.

p.#text: . I understand; here at this cottage , which is close by the Temple of , you've requested me to knock and ask for water.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Whose voice is it that has flown to my ears?

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA
sp.p: Prithee, who's speaking here? Who is it that I see?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Isn't this Ampelisca that's coming out from the Temple?

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA
sp.p: Isn't this Trachalio that I see, the servant of Plesidippus?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: It is she.

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA
sp.p: It is he; Trachalio, health to you.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Health, Ampelisca, to you; how fare you?

note.#text: :  She seems to mean that, in the prime of life her misfortunes are greater than might have been anticipated by one so young

p.#text: In misery I pass a life not far advanced.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Do give some better omen.

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA
sp.p: Still it behoves all prudent persons to confer and talk together. But, prithee, where's your master, Plesidippus?

p.#text: Marry, well said, indeed; as if he wasn't within there.

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA
sp.p: By my troth, he isn't, nor, in fact, has he come here at all.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: He hasn't come?

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA
sp.p: You say the truth.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: That's not my way, Ampelisca. But how nearly is the breakfast got ready?

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA
sp.p: What breakfast, I beg of you?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: The sacrifice, I mean, that you are performing here.

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA
sp.p: Prithee, what is it you are dreaming about?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: For certain, Labrax invited Plesidippus hither to a breakfast, your master, my master.

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA
sp.p: By my troth, you're telling of no wondrous facts: if he has deceived Gods and men, he has only acted after the fashion of Procurers.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Then neither yourselves nor my master are here performing a sacrifice.

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA
sp.p: You are a wizard.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: What are you doing then?

p.#text: The Priestess of  has received here into her abode both myself and Palstra, after many mishaps and dreadful alarm, and from being in danger of our lives, destitute of aid and of resources.

sp.speaker: TEACH.
sp.p: Prithee, is Palstra here, the beloved of my master?

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA
sp.p: Assuredly.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Great joyousness is there in your news, my dear Ampelisca. But I greatly long to know what was this danger of yours.

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA
sp.p: Last night our ship was wrecked, my dear Trachalio.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: How, ship? What story's this?

p.#text: Prithee, have you not heard in what way the Procurer intended secretly to carry us away hence to , and how, whatever there was at home, he placed on board ship? That has all gone to the bottom now.

note.#text: :  There is a joke here, which depends on the double meaning of "jacere bolum" and "perdere." The former signifies, "to cast a net" and "to cast a throw of dice." "Perdere" signifies, "to cause to perish," and "to break" or "ruin," in the gamester's sense.

p.#text: O clever , hail to thee! Surely, no dicer is more skilful than thyself. Decidedly a right pleasant throw hast thou made; thou didst break a-villain. But where now is the Procurer Labrax?
Perished through drinking, I suppose;  last night invited him to deep potations.

note.#text: :  "Anancum," "the cup of necessity," which derived its name from the Greek word  "necessity," was so called from the custom, in feasts, of handing round a large goblet, which all were obliged to empty, without losing a drop. Trachalio alludes to the large draught of salt water which he supposes Labrax has had to swallow at the bidding of .

p.#text: By my troth, I fancy it was given him to drink by way of cup of necessity. How much I do love you, my dear Ampelisca; how pleasing you are; what honied words you do utter. But you and Palstra, in what way were you saved?

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA
sp.p: I'll let you know. Both in affright, we leapt from the ship into a boat, because we saw that the ship was being borne upon a rock; in haste, I unloosed the rope, while they were in dismay. The storm separated us from them with the boat in a direction to the right. And so, tossed about by winds and waves, in a multitude of ways, we, wretched creatures, during the livelong night * * * * * * * half dead, the wind this day has scarce borne us to the shore.

note.#text: : -4. It was the duty of the diles at  to visit the markets and inspect the wares, like the Agoranomus, or "marketofficer," of the Greeks. See the Miles Gloriosus, l. 727, and the Note.

p.#text: I understand; thus is  wont to do; he is a very dainty dile; if any wares are bad, over he throws them all.

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA
sp.p: Woe to your head and life!

note.#text: :  It is supposed to have been the custom of soothsayers and diviners to let their hair grow to a greater length than usual

p.#text: To your own, my dear Ampelisca. I was sure that the Procurer would do that which he has done; I often said so. It were better I should let my hair grow, and set up for a soothsayer.

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA
sp.p: Did you not take care then, you and your master, that he shouldn't go away, when you knew this?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: What could he do?

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA
sp.p: If he was in love, do you ask what he could do? Both night and day he should have kept watch; he should have been always on his guard. But, by my troth, he has done like many others; thus finely has Plesidippus taken care of her.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: For what reason do you say that?

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA
sp.p: The thing is evident.

sp.speaker: TEACH.
sp.p: Don't you know this? Even he who goes to the bath to bathe, while there he carefully keeps an eye upon his garments, still they are stolen; inasmuch as some one of those that he is watching is a rogue; the thief easily marks him for whom he's upon the watch; the keeper knows not which one is the thief. But bring me to her; where is she?

p.#text: Well then, go here into the Temple of ; you'll find her sitting there, and in tears.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: How disagreable is that to me already. But why is she weeping?

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA
sp.p: I'll tell you; she's afflicting herself in mind for this; because the Procurer took away a casket from her which she had, and in which she kept that by which she might be enabled to recognize her parents; she fears that this has been lost.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Where was that little casket, pray?

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA
sp.p: There, on board the ship; he himself locked it up in his wallet, that there mightn't be the means by which she might recognize her parents.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: O scandalous deed! to require her to be a slave, who ought to be a free woman.

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA
sp.p: Therefore she now laments that it has gone to the bottom along with the ship. There, too, was all the gold and silver of the Procurer.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Some one, I trust, has dived and brought it up.

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA
sp.p: For this reason is she sad and disconsolate, that she has met with the loss of them.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Then have I the greater occasion to do this, to go in and console her, that she mayn't thus distress herself in mind. For I know that many a lucky thing has happened to many a one beyond their hopes.

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA
sp.p: But I know too that hope has deceived many who have hoped.

p.#text: Therefore a patient mind is the best remedy for affliction. I'll go in, unless you wish for anything.

stage: Knocking at the door of DMONES.
p.#text: I'll do that which the Priestess requested me, and I'll ask for some water here at the neighbour's; for she said that if I asked for it in her name, they would give it directly. And I do think that I never saw a more worthy old lady, one to whom I should think that it is more befitting for Gods and men to show kindness. How courteously, how heartily, how kindly, how, without the least difficulty, she received us into her home, trembling, in want, drenched, shipwrecked, half dead; not otherwise, in fact, than if we had been her own offspring. How kindly did she herself, just now, tucking up her garments, make the water warm for us to bathe. Now, that I mayn't keep her waiting, I'll fetch some water from the place where she requested me.  , there, is there any one in the cottage? is any one going to open this door? Will any one come out?

div2.stage: Enter SCEPARNIO, from the cottage of DMONES.

sp.speaker: SCEPARNIO
sp.p: Who is it so furiously making an attack upon our door?

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA
sp.p: It's I.

p.#text: Well now, what good news is there?  Dear me, a lass of comely appearance, i' troth.

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA
sp.p: Greeting to you, young man.

sp.speaker: SCEPARNIO
sp.p: And many greetings to you, young woman.

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA
sp.p: I'm come to you----

lemma.#text: For just now I've no means

note.#text: :  This line has greatly puzzled the Commentators. Sceparnio, however, seems to mean that at present he is busy, and cannot attend to her, but that in the evening he will be at her service. It has been suggested that a double entendre is meant; and such may possibly be the case, though the pungency of the passage is lost by reason of the hiatus in the next line. The meaning may, however, be harmless, and he may intend to say that at present he is busy thatching the house, but that at nightfall he will have finished, when she may count upon being hospitably entertained.

p.#text: I'll receive you with a welcome, if you come in the evening, by-and-by, just such as I could like; for just now I've no means to receive you, a damsel, thus early in the morning * * * But what have you to say, my smiling, pretty one.
Oh, you're handling me too familiarly.

note.#text: :  There is a poor joke here upon the words "subaquilum" and "subvulturium." Sceparnio means to describe the complexion of Ampelisca as somewhat resembling the colour of an eagle. By mistake, he happens to mention "a vulture," and immediately corrects himself, as, from its sordid habits, he may be deemed to be paying her an ill compliment.

p.#text: O ye immortal Gods! she's the very image of . What joyousness there is in her eyes, and, only do see, what a skin 'tis of the vulture's tint,--rather, the eagle's, indeed, I meant to say. Her breasts, too, how beautiful; and then what expression on her lips!

lemma.#text: No common commodity for the whole township

note.#text: :  "Pollucta pago." The portion of the sacrifice to  which was given to the common people was said to be "pollucta," whence the present adaptation of the epithet. Echard seems to have contemplated translating this, "I'm no pie for every one's cutting up!"

p.#text: . I'm no common commodity for the whole township; can't you keep your hands off me?
. Won't you let me touch you, gentle one, in this manner, gently and lovingly? * * * * * * * *

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA
sp.p: When I have leisure, then I'll be giving my attention to toying and dalliance to please you; for the present, prithee, do either say me "Yes" or "No" to the matter for which I was sent hither.

sp.speaker: SCEPARNIO
sp.p: What now is it that you wish?

p.#text: . To a shrewd person, my equipment would give indications of what it is I want.

sp.speaker: SCEPARNIO
sp.p: To a shrewd woman, this equipment, too, of mine, would give indication of what it is I want.

p.#text: . The Priestess there of , requested me to fetch some water from your house here.

sp.speaker: SCEPARNIO
sp.p: But I'm a lordly sort of person; unless you entreat me, you shan't have a drop. We dug this well with danger to ourselves, and with tools of iron. Not a drop can be got out of me except by means of plenty of blandishments.

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA
sp.p: Prithee, why do you make so much fuss about the water--a thing that even enemy affords to enemy?

sp.speaker: SCEPARNIO
sp.p: Why do you make so much fuss about granting a favour to me, that citizen grants to citizen?

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA
sp.p: On the contrary, my sweet one, I'll even do everything for you that you wish.

sp.speaker: SCEPARNIO
sp.p: O charming! I am favoured; she's now calling me her sweet one. The water shall be given you, so that you mayn't be coaxing me in vain. Give me the pitcher.

p.#text: Take it : make haste and bring it out, there's a dear.
Stay a moment; I'll be here this instant, my sweet one.  * * * * * * * * * * *

What shall I say to the Priestess for having delayed here so long a time? * * * * * * * How, even still, in my wretchedness do I tremble, when with my eyes I look upon the sea.  But what, to my sorrow, do I see afar upon the shore? My master, the Procurer, and his Sicilian guest. both of whom wretched I supposed to have perished in the deep. Still does thus much more of evil survive for us than we had imagined. But why do I delay to run off into the Temple, and to tell Palstra this, that we may take refuge at the altar before this scoundrel of a Procurer can come hither and seize us here? I'll betake myself away from this spot; for the necessity suddenly arises for me to do so.

div2.stage: Enter SCEPARNIO, from the cottage.

stage: Turning slowly round, he holds out the pitcher.
Goes into the Temple with the pitcher.

note.#text: :  "Prfiscine." This word was generally used as being supposed to avert the evil eye, when persons spake in high terms of themselves. There is some drollery in Sceparnio using it, when speaking in lisparagement of himself.
:  Not for the pleasure of loving, but for the comparative ease of drawing the water, which was probably one of his employments.
:  Both Horace and  mention the game of hiding, or "bo-peep," as a favorite one with the girls of their day

p.#text: . O ye immortal Gods, I never did imagine that there was so great delight in water; how heartily I did draw this. Thewell seemed much less deep than formerly. How entirely without exertion did I draw this up. With all deference to myself, am I not a very silly fellow,in having only to-day made a commencement of being in love?  Here's the water for you, my pretty one; here now, I would have you carry it with as much pleasure as I carry it, that you may please me.  But where are you, my tit-bit? Do take this water, please; where are you?  I' troth, she's in love with me, as I fancy; the roguish one's playing bo- peep. Where are you? Are you going now to take this pitcher? Where are you, I say? You've carried the joke far enough. Really, do be serious at last. Once more, are you going to take this pitcher? Where in the world are you?  I' troth, I don't see her anywhere, for my part; she's making fun of me. I' faith, I shall now set down this pitcher in the middle of the road. But yet, suppose any person should carry away from here this sacred pitcher of , he would be causing me some trouble. I' faith, I'm afraid that this woman's laying a trap for me, that I may be caught with the sacred pitcher of . In such case, with very good reason, the magistrate will be letting me die in prison, if any one shall see me holding this. For it's marked with the name; itself tells its own tale, whose property it is. Troth now, I'll call that Priestess here out of doors, that she may take this pitcher. I'll go there to the door.   there! Ptolemocratia.  Take this pitcher of yours, please; some young woman, I don't know who, brought it here to me.  It must then be carried in-doors by me. I've found myself a job, if, in fact, of my own accord, water is to be carried by me for these people as well.

div2.stage: Enter LABRAX, dripping wet, followed by CHARMIDES, at a distance, in the same plight.

note.#text: :  He probably alludes to some current proverb of the day, which may, with considerable truth, have said that liberty forsakes a man when he goes or board ship.

p.#text: . The person that chooses himself to be wretched and a beggar, let him trust himself and his life to . For if any one has any dealings at all with him, he sends him back home equipped in this guise.  By my troth, Liberty, you were a clever one, who were never willing to put even a foot, i' faith, on board ship with me. But  where's this guest of mine that has proved my ruin? Oh, see, here he comes.

sp.speaker: CHARMIDES
sp.p: Where the plague are you hurrying to, Labrax? For really I cannot follow you so fast.

p.#text: I only wish that you had perished by direful tornments in  before I had looked upon you with my eyes, you on whose account this misfortune has befallen me.

sp.speaker: CHARMIDES
sp.p: I only wish that on the day on which you admitted me into your house, I had laid me down in a prison sooner. I pray the immortal Gods, that so long as you live, you may have all your guests just like your own self.

note.#text: :  He means that he has not only lost his existing property by the shipwreck, but his hopes of profit as well on his arrival at , by means of his traffic with Palstra and Ampelisca.

p.#text: In your person I admitted misfortune into my house. What business had I to listen to a rogue like you, or what to depart hence? Or why to go on board ship, where I have lost even more wealth than I was possessor of?

sp.speaker: CHARMIDES
sp.p: Troth, I'm far from being surprised if your ship has been wrecked, which was carrying yourself, a villain, and your property villanously acquired.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: You've utterly ruined me with your wheedling speeches.

note.#text: :  Atreus killed the children of his brother Thyestes, and served them up to their father. Progne slew her son Itys, and set him before his father Tereus, who had ravished and mutilated her sister Philomela.

p.#text: A more accursed dinner of yours have I been dining upon than the ones that were set before Thyestes and Tereus.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: I'm dying; I'm sick at heart. Prithee, do hold up my head.

sp.speaker: CHARMIDES
sp.p: By my troth, I could very much wish that you would vomit up your lungs.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Alas! Palstra and Ampelisca, where are you now?

sp.speaker: CHARMIDES
sp.p: Supplying food for the fishes at the bottom, I suppose.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: You have brought beggary upon me by your means, while I was listening to your bragging lies.

note.#text: :  " Ex insulso salsum." The humour in this passage depends on the double meaning of the word "salsus," which signifies "saited," and, figuratively, "sharp," "clever." "witty."

p.#text: You have reason deservedly to give me many hearty thanks, who from an insipid morsel by my agency have made you salt.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Nay, but do you get out from me to extreme and utter perdition.

sp.speaker: CHARMIDES
sp.p: You be off; I was just going to do that very thing.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Alas! what mortal being is there living more wretched than I?

sp.speaker: CHARMIDES
sp.p: I am by very far much more wretched, Labrax, than yourself.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: CHARMIDES
sp.p: Because I am not deserving of it, whereas you are deserving.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: O bulrush, bulrush, I do praise your lot, who always maintain your credit for dryness.

note.#text: :   has this Note on this passage: "'Velitatio' signifies 'a skirmish,' which was. usually made by the 'velites,' that is, 'the light-harnessed soldiers;' and these men always made use of darts, whose points would glitter at a distance, sometimes one way, and sometimes another. Now Charmides, trembling with cold, compares himself to these 'velites,' or 'skirmishers,' who never keep their places; and his words, which came out broken and by piecemeal, to the unequal glimmerings or flashes of their darts"

p.#text: . For my part, I'm exercising myself for a skirmishing fight, for, from my shivering, I utter all my words in piecemeal flashes.

note.#text: :  See the Trinummus, l. 1013, and the Note.

p.#text: By my troth, Neptune, you are a purveyor of chilly baths; since I got away from you with my clothes, I've been freezing. No hot liquor-shop at all for sure does he provide; so salt and cold the potions that he prepares.

sp.speaker: CHARMIDES
sp.p: How lucky are the blacksmiths who are always sitting among hot coals; they are always warm.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: I only wish that I were now enjoying the lot of the duck, so as, although I had just come from out of the water, still to be dry.

note.#text: :  "Manducus" was a huge figure exhibited on the stage and at public shows, with huge teeth craunching, and a wide mouth--probably not unlike some of the idols of the South Sea Islanders.

p.#text: What if I some way or other let myself out at the games for a hobgoblin?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: For what reason?

sp.speaker: CHARMIDES
sp.p: Because, i' faith, I'm chattering aloud with my teeth. But I'm of opinion that, with very good reason, I've had this ducking.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: CHARMIDES
sp.p: Why, haven't I ventured to go on board ship with yourself, who have been stirring up the ocean for me from the very bottom?

p.#text: I listened to you when advising me; you assured me that there in  was very great profit from courtesans; there, you used to say, I should be able to amass wealth.
Did you expect, then, you unclean beast, that you were going to gobble up the whole island of ?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: What whale, I wonder, has gobbled up my wallet where all my gold and silver was packed up?

sp.speaker: CHARMIDES
sp.p: That same one, I suppose, that has swallowed my purse, which was full of silver in my travelling-bag.

p.#text: Alas! I'm reduced even to this one poor tunic  and to this poor shabby cloak; I'm done for to all intents.

sp.speaker: CHARMIDES
sp.p: Then you may even go into partnership with me; we have got equal shares.

p.#text: If at least my damsels had been saved, there would have been some hope. Now, if the young man Plesidippus should be seeing me, from whom I received the earnest for Palstra, he'll then be causing me some trouble in consequence.

note.#text: :  He means, that his readiness to commit perjury will save him the trouble of finding money to pay with as he can always swear that he has paid already.

p.#text: Why cry, you fool? Really, by my troth, so long as your tongue shall exist, you have abundance with which to make payment to everybody.

div2.stage: Enter SCEPARNIO, from the Temple.

p.#text: . What to-do is this, I'd like to know, that two young women here in the Temple, in tears, are holding in their embrace the statue of Venus, dreading I know not what in their wretchedness? But they say that this last night they have been tossed about, and to-day cast on shore from the waves.
. Troth now, young man, prithee, where are these young women that you are talking of?
Here  in the Temple of Venus.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: How many are there?

sp.speaker: SCEPARNIO
sp.p: Just as many as you and I make.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Surely, they are mine.

sp.speaker: SCEPARNIO
sp.p: Surely, I know nothing about that.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Of what appearance are they?

sp.speaker: SCEPARNIO
sp.p: Good-looking; I could even fall in love with either of them, if I were well liquored.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Surely, they are the damsels.

sp.speaker: SCEPARNIO
sp.p: Surely, you are a nuisance; be off, go in and see, if you like.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: These must be my wenches in here, my dear Charmides.

sp.speaker: CHARMIDES
sp.p: Jupiter confound you, both if they are and still if they are not.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: I'll straightway burst into this Temple of Venus here.

p.stage: LABRAX rushes into the Temple, and shuts the door.
p.#text: Into the bottomless pit, I would rather.   Prithee, stranger, show me some spot where I may go to sleep.
Go to sleep there, wherever you please ; no one hinders, it's free to the public.
. But do you see me, in what wet clothes I'm dressed? Do take me under shelter; lend me some dry clothes, while my own are drying; on some occasion I'll return you the favour.

p.stage: Takes it off and holds it out to him.
p.#text: See, here's my outer coat, which alone is dry; that, if you like, I'll lend you.  In that same I'm wont to be clothed, by that same protected, when it rains. Do you give me those clothes of yours; I'll soon have them dried.

note.#text: :  The poor joke here turns on the double meaning of the word "eluo," which, in the passive, means "to be shipwrecked," and in the active, either "to bathe" or "to be ruined in one's fortunes." It is not very dissimilar to an expression common with us, and might be rendered, "I wasn't cleaned out enough at sea fast night, but you want to clean me out still more." Sceparnio takes the word in the sense of "to bathe," and says, "Bathe or anoint yourself; I don't care a fig." Anointing followed immediately after bathing,

p.#text: How now, are you afraid that, as I've been washed bare last night at sea, I mayn't be made bare again here upon shore?

note.#text: :  "Ciccum." "Ciccum" was the thin skin in the pomegranate that divided the kernels.

p.stage: Puts on his coat again, and goes into the house of DMONES.
p.#text: Wash you bare, or anoint you well, I don't care one fig. I shall never entrust anything to you unless upon a pledge being taken. Do you either sweat away or perish with cold, be you either sick or well. I'll put up with no stranger-guest in my house; I've had disagreements enough.

note.#text: :  His meaning is, "he is so inhuman, that surely he is a slave-dealer, and nothing less."
:  "Non est misericors." Literally, "he is not merciful."
:  He uses this comparison because it was the custom of the ancients to mix sea-water with all the Greek wines, except the Chian, which Horace styles "maris expers," "unmixed with the sea."

p.#text: What, are you off?  He's a trafficker in slaves for money; whoever he is, he has no bowels of compassion. But why in my wretchedness am I standing here, soaking? Why don't I rather go away from here into the Temple of Venus, that I may sleep off this debauch which I got with drinking last night against the bent of my inclination? Neptune has been drenching us with salt water as though we were G-reek wines, and so he hoped that our stomachs might be vomited up with his salt draughts. What need of words? If he had persisted in inviting us a little longer, we should have gone fast asleep there; as it is, hardly alive has he sent us off home. Now I'll go see the Procurer, my boon companion, what he's doing within.

div2.stage: Enter DMONES, from his house.

stage: A loud noise is heard in the Temple.

note.#text: :  It is somewhat singular that the same three lines as this and the two following occur in the Mercator, at the beginning of Act II.

:  The Poets generally represent Progne as changed into a swallow, and Philomela into a nightingale. Ovid, however, on one occasion, mentions Philomela as being changed into a swallow. They were the daughters of Pandion, king of , the native place of Dmones.

p.#text: . In wondrous ways do the Gods make sport of men, in wondrous fashions do they send dreams in sleep. Not the sleeping, even, do they allow to rest. As, for example, I, this last night which has gone by, dreamed a wonderful and a curious dream. A she-ape seemed to be endeavouring to climb up to a swallow's nest; and she was not able thence to take them out. After that, the ape seemed to come to me to beg me to lend a ladder to her. I in these terms gave answer to the ape, that swallows are the descendants of Philomela and of Progne. I expostulated with her, that she might not hurt those of my country. But then she began to be much more violent, and seemed gratuitously to be threatening me with vengeance. She summoned me to a court of justice. Then, in my anger, I seemed to seize hold of the ape by the middle, in what fashion I know not; and I fastened up with chains this most worthless beast. Now to what purpose I shall say that this dream tends, never have I this day been able to come to any conclusion.  But what's this noise that arises in this Temple of Venus, my neighbour? My mind's in wonder about it.

div2.stage: Enter TRACHALIO, in haste, from the Temple.

p.#text: . O citizens of , I implore your aid, countrymen, you who are near neighbours to these spots, bring aid to helplessness, and utterly crush a most vile attempt. Inflict vengeance, that the power of the wicked, who wish themselves to be distinguished by crimes, may not be stronger than of the guiltless. Make an example for the shameless man, give its reward to modest virtue; cause that one may be allowed to live here rather under the control of the laws than of brute force. Hasten hither into the Temple of Venus; again do I implore your aid, you who are here at hand and who hear my cries. Bring assistance to those who, after the recognized usage, have entrusted their lives to Venus and to the Priestess of Venus, under their protection. Wring ye the neck of iniquity before it reaches yourselves.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: What's all this to-do?

p.#text: . By these knees of yours, I do entreat you, old gentleman, whoever you are----

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: Nay, but do you let go my knees, then, and tell me why it is that you are making a noise?

note.#text: :  "Sirpe" and "laserpitium" seem to be different names for the same plant, "laserwort," from which assaftida is distilled. It grew abundantly in Cyrene, which region Catullus calls "Laserpitifer Cyren." The juice of this plant seems to have been used in making certain perfumes, for which reason it was exported to .

At --Ver. 631.  was the chief city of , in , and was famed for its luxury. It was celebrated for its choice perfumes; and in it there was one great street called "Seplasia," which consisted entirely of shops, in which unguents and perfumes were sold.

p.#text: I do beg and entreat you, that if you hope this year that you will have abundance of laserwort and silphium, and that that export will arrive at  safe and sound, and that you may ever enjoy freedom from diseased eyes----

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: Are you in your senses?

note.#text: :  "Magudaris" is the root or juice of the plant called "laserpicium."

p.#text: ----Or whether you trust that you will have plenty of juice of silphium, that you will not hesitate to give me the aid which I shall entreat of you, aged sir.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: And I, by your legs, and ancles, and back, do entreat you that, if you hope that you will have a crop of elm-twigs, and that a fruitful harvest of beatings will this year be your lot, you will tell me what's the matter here, by reason of which you are making this uproar.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Why do you choose to speak me ill? For my part, I wished you everything that's good.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: And for my part, I'm speaking you well, in praying that things which you deserve may befall you.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Prithee, do prevent this.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: What's the matter, then?

p.#text: . Two innocent women are inside here, in need of your aid, on whom, against law and justice, an injury has been, is being, glaringly committed here in the Temple of Venus. Besides, the Priestess of Venus is being disgracefully insulted.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: What person is there of effrontery so great as to dare to injure the Priestess? But these women, who are they? Or what injury is being done to them?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: If you give me your attention, I'll tell you. They have clung to the statue of Venus; a most audacious fellow is now trying to tear them away. They ought, by rights, both of them to be free.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: What fellow is it that so lightly holds the Gods? In a few words tell me.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: One most full of fraud, villany, parricide, and perjury; a lawbreaker, an immodest, unclean, most shameless fellow; to sum up all in one word, he is a Procurer; why need I say more about him?

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: Troth now, you tell of a man that ought to be handed over to retribution.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: A villain, to seize the Priestess by the throat.

p.#text: By my troth, but he has done it at his own great peril.  Come you out of doors here, Turbalio and Sparax; where are you?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Prithee, do go in, and hasten to their rescue.

p.#text: . And am I to call for them once more?

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: Follow me this way.

note.#text: :  This, probably, was a practice of ancient cookery, which, happily, has not come down to our times.

p.#text: Come on now this instant, bid them tear his eyes out, just in the way that cooks do cuttle-fish.

p.stage: DMONES and his SERVANTS go into the Temple.
p.#text: Drag the fellow out here by his legs, just like a slaughtered pig.

. I hear a scuffling; the Procurer, I guess, is being belaboured with their fists; I'd very much like them to knock the teeth out of the jaws of the most villanous fellow. But see, here are the women themselves coming out of the Temple in consternation.

div2.stage: Enter PALSTRA and AMPELISCA, in haste, from the Temple, with dishevelled locks.

note.#text: :  "Signo intumo" may either mean the statue in the most distant and sacred recess, or the inner side of the statue, to which spot they had retired for safety.

p.#text: Now is that time arrived when destitution of all resources and aid, succour and defence, overtakes us. Neither hope nor means is there to bring us aid, nor know we in what direction we should commence to proceed. In exceeding terror now are we both, in this our wretchedness. Such cruelty and such outrage have been committed towards us just now in-doors here by our master, who, in his villany, pushed down the old lady, the Priestess, headlong, and struck her in a very disgraceful manner, and with his violence tore us away from the inner side of the statue. But as our lot and fortunes are now showing themselves, 'twere best to die, nor in our miseries is there anything better than death.
. What's this? Whose words are those? Why do I delay to console them?  Harkye, Palstra, Ampelisca, harkye!

sp.speaker: PALAESTRA
sp.p: Prithee, who is it that calls us?

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA
sp.p: Who is it that calls me by name?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: If you turn round and look, you'll know.

p.#text: . O hope of my safety!

note.#text: :  At the same time he is afraid to go in. Palstra sees this, and taunts him with being brave--in words only.

p.#text: Be silent and of good courage; trust me.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRA
sp.p: If only it can be so, let not violence overwhelm us.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: What violence?

sp.speaker: PALAESTRA
sp.p: That same which is driving me to commit violence on myself.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Oh, do leave off; you are very silly.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRA
sp.p: Then do you leave off at once your consoling me in my misery with words.

note.#text: :  "Re," "in reality," in contradistinction to words.

p.#text: Unless you afford us protection in reality, Trachalio, it's all over with us.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRA
sp.p: I'm resolved to die sooner than suffer this Procurer to get me in his power. But still I am of woman's heart; when, in my misery, death comes into my mind, fear takes possession of my limbs.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: By my troth, although this is a bitter affliction, do have a good heart.

sp.speaker: PALAESTRA
sp.p: Why where, pray, is a good heart to be found for me?

p.#text: Don't you fear, I tell you; sit you down here by the altar.

sp.speaker: AMPELISCA
sp.p: What can this altar possibly avail us more than the statue here within the Temple of Venus, from which just now, embracing it, in our wretchedness, we were torn by force?

note.#text: :  "Mnia." Madame Dacier supposes that these words refer to the walls of a court in front of the Temple, represented on the stage with an altar in the middle, the walls being breast high, which Trachalio compares to entrenchments.

p.#text: Only you be seated here; then I'll protect you in this spot. This altar you possess as though your bulwarks; these your fortifications; from this spot will I defend you. With the aid of Venus, I'll march against the wickedness of the Procurer.

p.stage: they advance to the altar and kneel

note.#text: :  "Bene lautum." There is a joke intended in the use of these words, which may signify either "quite tidy "or "properly arranged;" or, on the other hand, "well washed," neglect of which certainly could not be imputed to them, by reason of their recent shipwreck.

p.#text: We follow your instructions ; and genial Venus, we both of us, in tears, implore thee, embracing this thy altar, bending upon our knees, that thou wilt receive us into thy guardianship, and be our protector; that thou wilt punish those wretches who have set at nought thy Temple, and that thou wilt suffer us to occupy this thy altar with thy permission, we who last night were by the might of Neptune cast away; hold us not in scorn, and do not for that reason impute it to us as a fault, if there is anything that thou shouldst think is not so well attended to by us as it ought to have been.

note.#text: :  He alludes to the birth of Venus, who was said to have sprung from the sea in a shell. He also seems to joke upon the destitute state of the young women, and to call them mere shells. An indelicate construction has been, by some, put upon the use of the word "conchas," while others think it refers to the use made by women of shells, for holding their paints, perfumes, and cosmetics, and that he means thereby to reproach Venus for having allowed them to lose all their property. This, however, seems to be a rather far-fetched notion.

p.#text: I think they ask what's just; it ought, Venus, by thee to be granted. Thou oughtst to pardon them; 'tis terror forces them to do this. They say that thou wast born from a shell; take thou care that thou dost not despise the shells of these. But see, most opportunely the old gentleman is coming out, both my protector and your own.

div2.stage: Enter DMONES, from the Temple, with his two SERVANTS dragging out LABRAX.

stage: Not seeing them near the door.
p.#text: Come out of the Temple, you most sacrilegious of men, as many as have ever been born. Do you go  and sit by the altar.  But where are they?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Look round here.

stage: To the SERVANTS, who obey with alacrity.

note.#text: :  He means that the women have done as he wished them to do, in flying to the altar for refuge.

p.#text: . Very good; I wanted that. Now bid him come this way.  Are you attempting here among us to commit a violation of the laws against the Deities?  Punch his face with your fists.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: I'm suffering these indignities at your own cost.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: Why, the insolent fellow's threatening even.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: I've been robbed of my rights; you are robbing me of my female slaves against my will.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Do you then find some wealthy man of the Senate of Cyrene as judge, whether these women ought to be yours, or whether they oughtn't to be free, or whether it isn't right that you should be clapped into prison, and there spend your life, until you have worn the whole gaol out with your feet.

note.#text: :  "Furcifero." He sneeringly alludes to Trachalio's position as a slave, and his liability to have the punishment of the "furca" inflicted on him.

p.#text: I wasn't prepared to prophesy for this day that I should be talking with a hang-gallows like yourself.  You do I summon to judgment.
. In the first place, try it with him who knows you.
. My suit is with yourself.
But it must be with myself.  Are these your female slaves?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: They are.

sp.speaker: TRACL.
sp.p: Just come then, touch either of them with your little finger only.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: What if I do touch them?

note.#text: : -2. These lines are thus rendered in one version: "Instantly I will make you a prize-fighting pair of bellows, and while you are drawing breath, will belabour you with my fists." The allusion, however, is clearly to a ball blown up like our footballs, and struck with the clenched fist, the merit of the game being not to let it come to the ground.

p.#text: That very instant, upon my faith, I'll make a hand-ball of you, and while you're in the air I'll belabour you with my fists, you most perjured villain.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Am I not to be allowed to take away my female slaves from the altar of Venus?

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: You may not; such is the law with us.

note.#text: :  "Foras." Probably in allusion to the court before the Temple

p.#text: I've no concern with your laws; for my part, I shall at once carry them both away from here. If you are in love with them, old gentleman , you must down here with the ready cash.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: But these women have proved pleasing to Venus.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: She may have them, if she pays the money.

note.#text: :  "Myrteta." This may allude to bundles of myrtle (which was sacred to Venus), bound with rushes and hung about the Temple, or else to beds of myrtle in front of the Temple, with small fences round them, made of rushes.

p.#text: A Goddess, pay you money? Now then, that you may understand my determination, only do you commence in mere joke to offer them the very slightest violence; I'll send you away from here with such a dressing, that you won't know your own self. You, therefore , when I give you the signal, if you don't beat his eyes out of his head, I'll trim you round about with rods just like beds of myrtle with bulrushes.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: You are treating me with violence.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: What, do you even upbraid us with violence, you flagrant specimen of flagitiousness?

note.#text: :  "Trifurcifer." Literally, "one punished with the 'furca' three times," meaning a "thief;" or "villain three times over." See the Aulularia, l. 281, and the Note (where read "punished with the 'furca'")

p.#text: You, you thrice-dotted villain, do you dare to speak abusively to me?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: I am a thrice-dotted villain; I confess it; you are a strictly honorable man; ought these women a bit the less to be free?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: What--free?

note.#text: :  Perhaps in contradistinction to , which was only colonized by Greeks.

p.#text: Aye, and your mistresses, too, i' faith, and from genuine ; for one of them was born at  of free-born parents.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: What is it I hear from you?

p.#text: That she  was born at , a free-born woman.
. Prithee is she a countrywoman of mine?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Are you not a Cyrenian?

p.#text: No; born at  in , bred and educated there.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Prithee, aged sir, do protect your countrywomen.

p.#text: . O daughter, when I look on her, separated from me you remind me of my miseries:  she who was lost by me when three years old; now, if she is living, she's just about as tall, I'm sure, as she.
I paid the money down for these two, to their owners, of whatever country they were. What matters it to me whether they were born at  or at , so long as they are rightfully in servitude as my slaves?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: it so, you impudent fellow? What, are you, a cat prowling after maidens, to be keeping children here kidnapped from their parents and destroying them in your disgraceful calling? But as for this other one, I really don't know what her country is; I only know that she's more deserving than yourself, you most abominable rascal.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Are these women your property?

note.#text: :  "Offerumenta," according to Festus, signified an offering to the Gods; and as these were fixed to the walls of the Temples, Trachalio calls the lashes of the scourge or rod, when applied to the back of the delinquent slave, by the same term.
:  "Longa navis." Literally, "a long ship." Ships of war were thus called by the Greeks.
:  "Ampullarius." "A maker of ampull,' or leather bottles. They were of a big-bellied form, with a narrow neck.

p.#text: Come to the trial, then, which of the two according to his back is the more truthful; if you don't bear more compliments upon your back than any ship of war has nails, then I'm the greatest of liars. Afterwards, do you examine mine, when I've examined yours; if it shall not prove to be so untouched, that any leather flask maker will say that it is a hide most capital and most sound for the purposes of his business, what reason is there why I shouldn't mangle you with stripes, even till you have your belly full? Why do you stare at them? If you touch them I'll tear your eyes out.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Yet notwithstanding, although you forbid me to do so, I'll at once carry them off both together with me.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: What will you do?

note.#text: :  In so saying, he alludes to the intrigue of Venus with , which was discovered by the device of , her injured husband. For the story, see the Metamorphoses of , B. 4, l. 73, and the Art of Love, B. 2, l. 562.

p.#text: I'll bring ; he is an enemy to Venus.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Whither is he going?

p.#text: . ! Is there anybody here? ! I say.

note.#text: :  "Mergis pugneis." Echard, in his translation, explains this: "As they lift up their pitchforks to heap corn, so will I lift up my fists, and heap a whole harvest of cuffs on your face." "Merga' means 'a pitchfork;" and, according to , it was so called from its resemblance when dipped into the hay to the action of the "mergus," or "didapper when dipping into the sea,

p.#text: If you touch the door, that very instant, upon my faith, you shall get a harvest upon your face with fists for your pitchforks.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: We keep no fire, we live upon dried figs.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: I'll find the fire, if only I have the opportunity of kindling it upon your head.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Faith, I'll go somewhere to look for some fire.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: What, when you've found it?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: I'll be making a great fire here.

note.#text: :   tells us that "humanum" was a "mortuary sacrifice," or "offering to the dead." In his question, therefore, Dmones inplies a wish to know whether Labrax is about to put an end to himself. It was allowable to drive away those who fled to the altar by the agency of fire.

p.#text: What, to be burning a mortuary sacrifice for yourself?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: No, but I'll burn both of these alive here upon the altar.

p.#text: I'd like that. For, by my troth, I'll forthwith seize you by the head and throw you into the fire, and, half-roasted, I'll throw you out as food for the great birds.  When I come to a consideration of it with myself, this is that ape, that wanted to take away those swallows from the nest against my will, as I was dreaming in my sleep.

sp.speaker: TPACH.
sp.p: Aged sir, do you know what I request of you? That you will protect these females and defend them from violence, until I fetch my master.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: Go look for your master, and fetch him here.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: But don't let him----

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: At his own extreme peril, if he touches them, or if he attempts to do so.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Take care.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: Due care is taken; do you be off.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: And watch him too, that he doesn't go away anywhere. For we have promised either to give the executioner a great talent, or else to produce this fellow this very day.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: Do you only be off. I'll not let him get away, while you are absent.

p.#text: I'll be back here soon.

div2.stage: DMONES, LABRAX, PALSTRA, AMPELISCA, and SERVANTS.

p.stage: to LABRAX, who is struggling with the SERVANTS
p.#text: . Which, you Procurer, had you rather do, be quiet with a thrashing, or e'en as it is, without the thrashing, if you had the choice?
Old fellow, I don't care a straw for what you say. My own women, in fact, I shall drag away this instant from the altar by the hair, in spite of yourself, and , and supreme Jove.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: Just touch them.

p.#text: I' troth, I surely will touch them.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: Just come then; only approach this way.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Only bid both those fellows, then, to move away from there.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: On the contrary, they shall move towards you.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: I' faith, for my own part, I don't think so.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: If they do move nearer to you, what will you do?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
