sp.p: I'll retire. But, old fellow, if ever I catch you in the city, never again, upon my faith, shall any one call me a Procurer, if I don't give you some most disagreable sport.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: Do what you threaten. But now, in the meantime, if you do touch them, a heavy punishment shall be inflicted on you.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: How heavy, in fact?

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: Just as much as is sufficient for a Procurer.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: These threats of yours I don't value one straw; I certainly shall seize them both this instant without your leave.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: Just touch them.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: By my troth, I surely will touch them.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: You will touch them, but do you know with what result? Go then, Turbalio, with all haste, and bring hither from out of the house two cudgels.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Cudgels?

p.#text: Aye, good ones; make haste speedily.  I'll let you have a reception this day in proper style, as you are deserving of.
. Alas! cursedly unfortunate. I lost my headpiece in the ship; it would now have been handy for me, if it had been saved.  May I at least address these women?
You may not * * * * *  Well now, by my faith, look, the cudgel-man is coming very opportunely here.
. By my troth, this surely is a tingling for my ears.

stage: They stand with lifted cudgels on each side of he altar.

note.#text: :  "Invitos--invitassitis." He here plays upon the resemblance of the words "invitos," signifying "against their will," and "invito," being a verb signifying "to invite," and admitting of much the same equivocal use as our expression, "to give a warm reception to."

p.#text: Come, Sparax, do you take this other cudgel.  Come, take your stand, one on one side, the other on one other. Take your stations both of you.  Just so. Now then attend to me: if, i' faith, that fellow there should this day touch these women with his finger against their inclination, if you don't give him a reception with these cudgels even to that degree that he shan't know which way he is to get home, you are undone, both of you. If he shall call for any one, do you make answer to this fellow in their stead. But if he himself shall attempt to get away from here, that instant, as hard a you can, lay on to his legs with your sticks.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Are they not even to allow me to go away from here?

p.#text: I've said sufficient. And when that servant comes here with his master, he that has gone to fetch his master, do you at once go home. Attend to this with great diligence, will you.

note.#text: :  Seeing the servants with their cudgels, he is reminded of Hercules, who was thus depicted, and was called by the Poets "Claviger."

p.#text: O rare, by my troth, the Temple here is surely changed all of a sudden; this is now the Temple of  which was that of  before; in such fashion has the old fellow planted two statues here with clubs. I' faith, I don't know now whither in the world I shall fly from here; so greatly are they both raging now against me, both land and sea. Palstra!

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: What do you want?

note.#text: :  Echard, borrowing the notion from Madame Dacier, has the following Note on this passage: "This 'Palstra' was a place of public exercise, over the gate of which was a statue of , with an inscription 'Palstra;' now Labrax, finding this stout fellow with his club, whom before he had compared to , answering instead of Palstra, he wittily alludes to that statue, and says that that Palstra was none of his."  appears to be right in considering this a far-fetched conceit on the part of the fair Commentatress.

p.#text: Away with you, there is a misunderstanding between us; that, indeed, is not my Palstra that answers. Harkye, Ampelisca.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Beware of a mishap, will you.

p.#text: . So far as they can, the worthless fellows advise me rightly enough.  But, harkye, I ask you, whether it is any harm to you for me to come nearer to these women?

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Why none at all to ourselves.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Will there be any harm to myself?

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: None at all, if you only take care.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: What is it that I'm to take care against?

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Why, look you, against a heavy mishap.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Troth now, prithee, do let me approach them.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Approach them, if you like.

p.#text: I' faith, obligingly done; I return you thanks, I'll go nearer to them.

p.stage: Drags him to his place, with the cudgel over his head.
p.#text: Do you stand there on the spot, where you are.
. By my faith, I've come scurvily off in many ways. Still, I'm resolved to get the better of them this day by constantly besieging them.

div2.stage: Enter PLESIDIPPUS and TRACHALIO, at a distance, on the other side of the stage.

p.#text: And did the Procurer attempt by force and violence to drag my mistress away from the altar of ?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Even so.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: Why didn't you kill him on the instant?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: I hadn't a sword.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: You should have taken either a stick or a stone.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: What! ought I to have pelted this most villanous fellow with stones like a dog? * * * * * * * * *

p.#text: . By my troth, but I'm undone now; see, here's Plesidippus; he'll be sweeping me away altogether this moment with the dust.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: Were the damsels sitting on the altar even then when you set out to come to me?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Yes, and now they are sitting in the same place.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: Who is now protecting them there?

p.#text: Some old gentleman, I don't know who, a neighbour of the Temple of --he gave very kind assistance; he is now protecting them with his servants--I committed them to his charge.
Lead me straight to the Procurer. Where is this fellow?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Health to you.

note.#text: :  "Rapin te obtorto collo." Echard has the following Note: "When any person was brought before the Prtor, they always threw his gown or cloak about his neck, and led him that way; and this was called 'rapi obtorto collo."'

p.#text: I want none of your healths. Make your choice quickly, whether you lad rather be seized by your throat wrenched, or be dragged along; choose whichever you please, while you may.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: I wish for neither.

p.#text: Be off then, Trachalio, with all speed to the sea-shore; bid those persons that I brought with me to hand over this rascal to the executioner, to come from the harbour to the city to meet me; afterwards return hither and keep guard here. I'll now drag this scoundrelly outcast to justice. . Come, proceed to a court of justice.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: In what have I offended?

p.#text: Do you ask? Didn't you receive an earnest of me for this woman , and carry her off from here?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: I didn't carry her off.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: Why do you deny it?

note.#text: :  There is a play or quibble here upon the words "avehere" and "provehere," "to carry away," and "to put on board ship," for the purpose of being carried away.

p.#text: Troth now, because I put her on board ship; carry her off unfortunately, I couldn't. For my part, I told you that this day I would make my appearance at the Temple of ; have I swerved at all from that? Am I not there?
Plead your cause in the court of justice; here a word is enough. Follow me.
. I entreat you, my dear Charmides, do come to my rescue; I am being seized with my throat wrenched.
. Who calls my name?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Do you see me how I'm being seized?

sp.speaker: CHARMIDES
sp.p: I see, and view it with pleasure.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Don't you venture to assist me?

sp.speaker: CHARMIDES
sp.p: What person is seizing you?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Young Plesidippus.

sp.speaker: CHARMIDES
sp.p: What you've got, put up with; 'twere better for you, with a cheerful spirit, to slink to gaol; that has befallen you which many greatly wish for for themselves.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: CHARMIDES
sp.p: To find for themselves that which they are seeking.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: I entreat you, do follow me.

sp.speaker: CHARMIDES
sp.p: You try to persuade me, just like what you are: you are being taken off to gaol, for that reason is it you entreat me to follow you?

p.#text: . Do you still resist?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: I'm undone.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: I trust that may prove the truth. You, my dear Palstra and Ampelisca, do you remain here in the meanwhile, until I return hither.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: I would advise them rather to go to our house, until you return.

p.stage: The SERVANTS open the door of the cottage, and PALSTRA and AMPELISCA go in.
p.#text: I'm quite agreable; you act obligingly.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: You are thieves to me.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: How, thieves?

p.#text: Lead him along.
. I pray and entreat you, Palstra.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: Follow, you hang-dog.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Guest, Charmides!

sp.speaker: CHARMIDES
sp.p: I am no guest of yours; I repudiate your hospitality.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: What, do you slight me in this fashion?

note.#text: :  He alludes to the drenching he has had in the sea, by reason of his acquaintance with Labrax, and means to say that one such reception is quite sufficient for his life.

p.#text: I do so; I've been drinking with you once already.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: May the Deities confound you.

p.stage: PLESIDIPPUS leads LABRAX off, followed by the SERVANTS.

note.#text: :  He puns upon the resemblance between the word "columbar," "a collar," into which the head was inserted by way of punishment, and "columbus," a "pigeon." The notion of preserving the pun, by using the word "stock-dove," is Echard's. The plural of the word "columbar" was also used to signify a dove-cot.

p.#text: To that person of yours, say that.   I do believe that men are transformed, each into a different beast. That Procurer, I guess, is transformed into a stock-dove; for, before long, his neck will be in the stocks. He'll to-day be building his nest in the gaol. Still, however, I'll go, that I may be his advocate,--if by my aid he may possibly be sentenced any the sooner.

note.#text: Echard remarks that the interval between the last Act and this is filled up with Plesidippus carrying Labrax before the Prtor and his trial, an, likewise with what passes in Dmones' house.

p.#text: 'Twas rightly done, and it is a pleasure this day for me to have given aid to these young women; I have now found some dependants, and both of them of comely looks and youthful age. But my plaguy wife is watching me in all ways, lest I should be giving any hint to the young women. But I wonder what in the world my servant Gripus is about, who went last night to the sea to fish. Troth, he had done wiser if he had slept at home; for now he throws away both his pains and his nets, seeing what a storm there now is and was last night. I'll thoroughly cook upon my fingers what he has caught to-day; so violently do I see the ocean heaving.  But my wife's calling me to breakfast; I'll return home. She'll now be filling my ears with her silly prating.

div2.stage: Enter GRIPUS, dragging a net enclosing a wallet, by a rope.

stage: Gathers up the net, and drags it after him.

note.#text: :  The slave about to be manumitted, or to receive his freedom, was taken before the Prtor, whose lictor laid the "vindicta" or "festuca," "the rod of liberty," on the head of the slave, on which he received his freedom.
:  Is not this wonderfully like Alnaschar's reverie in the Arabian Nights, so aptly quoted in the Spectator?
:  He was the treasurer of Philip of  and Alexander the Great, and was famed for his wealth among the Greeks, as Crassus was among the Romans.
:  He alludes to the "posca," or vinegar and water, which formed the beverage of the slaves, and which is mentioned by Palstrio in the Miles Gloriosus, l. 836.

p.#text: . These thanks do I return to , my patron, who dwells in the salt retreats, the abode of fishes, inasmuch as he has despatched me finely laden on my return from his retreats, and from his Temples, laden with most abundant booty, with safety to my boat, which in the stormy sea made me master of a singular and rich haul. In a wondrous and incredible manner has this haul turned out prosperously for me, nor yet have I this day taken a single ounce weight of fish, but only that which I am here bringing with me in my net. For when I arose in the middle of the night, and without sloth, I preferred profit to sleep and rest; in the raging tempest, I determined to try how I might lighten the poverty of my master and my own servitude, not sparing of my own exertions. Most worthless is the man that is slothful, and most detestably do I hate that kind of men. It behoves him to be vigilant who wishes to do his duty in good time; for it befits him not to be waiting until his master arouses him to his duties. For those who sleep on for the love of it, rest without profit to themselves and to their own cost. But now I, who have not been slothful, have found that for myself through which to be slothful if I should choose.  This have I found in the sea to-day; whatever's in it, it's something heavy that's in it; I think it's gold that's in it. And not a single person is there my confidant in the matter. Now, Gripus, this opportunity has befallen you, that the Prtor might make you a free man from among the multitude. Now, thus shall I do, this is my determination; I'll come to my master cleverly and cunningly, little by little I'll promise money for my freedom, that I may be free. Now, when I shall be free, then, in fine, I'll provide me land and houses and slaves: I'll carry on merchandize with large ships: among the grandees I shall be considered a grandee. Afterwards, for the sake of pleasing myself, I'll build me a ship and I'll imitate Stratonicus, and I'll be carried about from town to town. When my greatness is far-spread, I shall fortify some great city: to that city I shall give the name of "Gripus," a memorial of my fame and exploits, and there I'll establish a mighty kingdom. I am resolving here in my mind to prepare for mighty matters. At present I'll hide this booty. But this grandee  is about to breakfast upon vinegar and salt, without any good substantial meat.

div2.stage: Enter TRACHALIO, in haste.

p.#text: there! stop.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Why should I stop?

note.#text: :  This is the first mention of the "rudens," or "netrope," from which the Play derives its name.

p.#text: While I coil up this rope for you that you are dragging.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Now let it alone.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Troth, but I'll assist you. What's kindly done to worthy men, isn't thrown away.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: * * * * * There was a boisterous tempest yesterday; no fish have I, young man; don't you be supposing I have. Don't you see that I'm carrying my dripping net without the scaly race?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: I' faith, I'm not wishing for fish so much as I am in need of your conversation.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Then, whoever you are, you are worrying me to death with your annoyance.

p.#text: . I'll not allow you to go away from here; stop.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Take you care of a mishap, if you please; but why the plague are you dragging me back?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Listen.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: I won't listen.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: But, upon my faith, you shall listen.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Nay but, another time, tell me what you want.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Come now, it's worth your while at once to hear what I want to tell you.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Say on, whatever it is.

p.#text: See whether any person is following near us.  GRIP. Why, what reason is there that it should matter to me?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: So it is; but can you give me some good advice?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: What's the business? Only tell me.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: I'll tell you; keep silence; if only you'll give me your word that you won't prove treacherous to me.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: I do give you my word; I'll be true to you, whoever you are.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Listen. I saw a person commit a theft; I knew the owner to whom that same property belonged. Afterwards I came myself to the thief, and I made him a proposal in these terms: "I know the person on whom that theft was committed; now if you are ready to give me half, I'll not make a discovery to the owner." He didn't even give me an answer. What is it fair should be given me out of it? Half, I trust you will say.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Aye, even more; but unless he gives it you, I think it ought to be told to the owner.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: I'll act on your advice. Now give me your attention; for it is to yourself all this relates.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: What has been done by me?

p.#text: . I've known the person for a long time to whom that wallet belongs.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: And in what manner it was lost.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: But I know in what manner it was found; and I know the person who found it, and who is now the owner. That, i' faith, is not a bit the more your matter than it is my own. I know the person to whom it now belongs; you, the person to whom it formerly belonged. This shall no individual get away from me; don't you be expecting to get it in a hurry.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: If the owner comes, shan't he get it away?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: That you mayn't be mistaken, no born person is there that's owner of this but my own self--who took this in my own fishing.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Was it really so?

lemma.#text: Claimed as having a right to freedom

note.#text: :  "Manu asserere" was "to assert" or "claim the liberty of a slave by action at law." Gripus applies the term to the fish of the sea, and means to say that when he catches them, he sells them as his own "venales," or "slaves."

p.#text: Which fish in the sea will you say "is my own?" When I catch them, if indeed I do catch them, they are my own; as my own I keep them. They are not claimed as having a right to freedom nor does any person demand a share in them. In the market I sell them all openly as my own wares. Indeed, the sea is, surely, common to all persons.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: I agree to that; prithee, then, why any the less is it proper that this wallet should be common to me? It was found in the sea.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Assuredly you are an outrageously impudent fellow; for if this is justice which you are saying, then fishermen would be ruined. Inasmuch as, the moment that the fish were exposed upon the stalls, no one would buy them; every person would be demanding his own share of the fish for himself; he would be saying that they were caught in the sea that was common to all.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: What do you say, you impudent fellow? Do you dare to compare a wallet with fish? Pray, does it appear to be the same thing?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: The matter doesn't lie in my power; when I've cast my hook and net into the sea, whatever has adhered I draw out. Whatever my net and hooks have got, that in especial is my own.

note.#text: :  "Vas." An utensil or article that is manufactured.

p.#text: Nay but, i' faith, it is not; if, indeed, you've fished up any article that's made

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Philosopher, you.

note.#text: :  "Vitor," or "vietor," was a maker of "viduli," or "wallets," which were made of osier, and then covered with leather of various colours.

p.#text: But look now, you conjurer, did you ever see a fisherman who caught a wallet-fish, or exposed one for sale in the market? But, indeed, you shan't here be taking possession of all the profits that you choose; you expect, you dirty fellow, to be both a maker of wallets and a fisherman. Either you must show me a fish that is a wallet, or else you shall carry nothing off that wasn't produced in the sea and has no scales.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: What, did you never hear before to-day that a wallet was a fish?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Villain, there is no such fish.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Yes, there certainly is; I, who am a fisherman, know it. But it is seldom caught; no fish more rarely comes near the land.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: It's to no purpose; you hope that you can be cheating me, you rogue. Of what colour is it?

p.#text: . Of this colour very few are caught: some are of a purple skin, there are great and black ones also.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: I understand; by my troth, you'll be turning into a wallet-fish I fancy, if you don't take care; your skin will be purple, and then afterwards black.

p.#text: . What a villain this that I have met with to-day!

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: We are wasting words; the day wears apace. Consider, please, by whose arbitration do you wish us to proceed?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: By the arbitration of the wallet.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Really so, indeed? You are a fool.

note.#text: :  Thales of  was one of the seven wise men of . Gripus ironically calls Trachalio by this name, in reply to the other having called him a fool.

p.#text: My respects to you, Mister
. You shan't carry that off this day, unless you find a place of safe keeping for it, or an umpire, by whose arbitration this matter may be settled.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Prithee, are you in your senses?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: I'm mad, in need of hellebore.

p.#text: But I'm troubled with sprites; still I shan't let this go.

Only add a single word more, that instant I'll drive my fists smash into your brains. This instant on this spot, just as a new napkin is wont to be wrung, I'll wring out of you whatever moisture there is, if you don't let this go.

note.#text: :  The polypus not being eatable, the fishermen would throw it violently on the ground on finding it in the nets.

p.#text: Touch me; I'll dash you down on the ground just in such fashion as I'm in the habit of doing with a polypus fish. Would you like to fight?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: What need is there? Nay, in preference, divide the booty.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: You can't get anything from here but harm to yourself, so don't expect it. I'm taking myself off.

p.stage: Stands in front of him, and holds the rope.
p.#text: But I'll turn aside your ship from that direction, that you mayn't be off anywhere--stop.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: If you are the helmsman of this ship, I'll be the pilot. Let go of the rope now, you villain.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: I will let go; do you let go of the wallet.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: I' faith, you shall never this day become a scrap the more wealthy from this.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: You cannot convince me by repeatedly denying, unless either a part is given me, or it is referred to arbitration, or it is placed in safe keeping.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: What, that which I got out of the sea----?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: But I spied it out from the shore.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: --With my own pains and labour, and net and boat.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: If now the owner, whose property it is, were to come, how am I, who espied from afar that you had taken this, a bit the less the thief than yourself?

p.#text: None whatever.
. Stop, you whip-knave; just let me learn of you by what reasoning I am not the sharer, and yet the thief.
I don't know; neither do I know these city laws of yours, only that I affirm that this is mine.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: And I, too, say that it is mine.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Stay now; I've discovered by what method you may be neither thief nor sharer.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: By what method?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Let me go away from here; you quietly go your own way, and don't you inform against me to any one, and I won't give anything to you. You hold your tongue; I'll be mum. This is the best and the fairest plan.

sp.speaker: TRACE.
sp.p: Well, what proposition do you venture to make?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: I've made it already; for you to go away, to let go of the rope, and not to be a nuisance to me.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Stop while I propose terms.

note.#text: : -2. He plays on the resemblance of the words , "to make a proposal," and , "to betake one's self away,"

p.#text: I' faith, do, prithee, dispose of yourself forthwith.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Do you know any one in these parts?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: My own neighbours I must know.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Where do you live here?

p.#text: . At a distance out away yonder, as far off as the farthest fields.

p.stage: pointing to the cottage of DMONES

For my part, I neither ask for a share of that wallet there, nor have I ever said this day that it is my own; but in it there is a little casket that belongs to this female , whom a short time since I averred to be free born.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Just so; and those trinkets which formerly, when little, she used to wear, are there in that casket, which is in that wallet. This thing is of no service to him, and will be of utility to her, poor creature, if he gives it up, by means of which to seek for her parents.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: I'll make him give it up; hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: I' faith, I'm going to give nothing to that fellow.

As kidnapping was in ancient times much more prevalent than now, these little articles, if carefully preserved by the child, might be the means of leading to the discovery of its parents; at the same time it may be Justly asked how it came to pass that the kidnapper should allow such damning evidence of his villany to remain in existence.

p.#text: I ask for nothing but the casket and the trinkets.

sp.p: What if they are made of gold?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: What's that to you? Gold shall be paid for gold, silver shall have its weight in silver in return.

sp.p: Please let me see the gold; after that I'll let you see the casket.

sp.speaker: DM.

p.#text: There ought to be a casket of wicker-work in that wallet, in which are tokens by means of which she may be enabled to recognize her parents, by whom, when little, she was lost at , as I said before.
May  and the Gods confound you. What do you say, you sorcerer of a fellow? What, are these women dumb, that they are not able to speak for themselves?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: They are silent for this reason, because a silent woman is always better than a talking one.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Then, i' faith, by your way of speaking, you are neither a man nor a woman to my notion.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: How so?

p.#text: Why, because neither talking nor silent are you ever good for anything. Prithee , shall I ever be allowed to-day to speak?

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: If you utter a single word more this day, I'll break your head for you.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: As I had commenced to say it, old gentleman, I beg you to order him to give up that casket to these young women; if for it he asks any reward for himself, it shall be paid; whatever else is there besides, let him keep for himself.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Now at last you say that, because you are aware it is my right; just now you were asking to go halves.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: Aye, and even still I ask it.

sp.p: I've seen a kite making a swoop, even when he got nothing at all however.

. If that fellow is silent, I'll be silent; if he talks, allow me to talk in my own behalf.

note.#text: :  The "bulla" was a ball of metal, so called from its resemblance in shape to a drop or bubble of water. These were especially worn by the Roman children, suspended from the neck, and were generally made of thin plates of gold, of about the size of a walnut. The use of them was derived from the people of Etruria, and though originally used solely by the children of the Patricians, they were subsequently worn by all of free birth. The children of the "libertini," or "freed-men," wore "bull," but made of leather. The "bulla" was laid aside at the same time as the "toga prtexta," and was on that occasion consecrated to the Lares. It must be owned that the "little sow," mentioned in the line before, was rather a curious soit of trinket. Thornton thinks that the word "sucula" admitted of a double entendre, though of what nature is now unknown.

p.#text: There's also a golden drop, which my father presented to me upon my birthday.

p.#text: O ye immortal Gods, what person is there more fortunate than I, who unexpectedly have discovered my daughter? I this day, a thing that I never hoped for nor yet believed, have unexpectedly discovered my daughter, and I shall bestow her upon a respectable young man of noble family, an Athenian, and my kinsman. For that reason I wish him to be fetched hither to me as soon as possible, and I've requested my servant to come out here, that he may go to the Forum. sp.p: Tell him that I'll give him my daughter for a wife.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO

sp.p: Very well.

sp.p: And let your daughter request it; she'll easily prevail.

sp.speaker: DM.

sp.p: And that I may experience a pleasing return to myself in kindness for my actions.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: What, all very well?

sp.p: Very well. Again I return you thanks. But do you make haste to proceed to the city forthwith, and betake yourself hither again.

sp.p: Touching that wallet, if you are wise, be wise; keep what goods the Gods provide you.

sp.speaker: DM.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS

sp.p: So much the better does it happen for him who lost it; none the more is it necessary that it should be your wallet.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: For this reason are you poor because you are too scrupulously righteous.

note.#text: :  This passage is very obscure, and has been variously interpreted. He seems, however, to mean that more good will come of restoring the booty to its owner than of keeping it.

p.#text: O Gripus, Gripus, in the life of man very many traps there are, in what they are deceived by guile. And, by my troth, full often is a bait placed in them, which bait if any greedy person greedily snaps at, through his own greediness he is caught in the trap. He who prudently, skilfully, and warily, takes precaution, full long he may enjoy that which is honestly acquired. This booty seems to me to be about to be made a booty of by me, that it may go hence with a greater blessing than it first came. What, ought I to conceal what I know was brought to me as belonging to another? By no means will my friend Dmones do that. 'Tis ever most becoming for prudent men to be on their guard against this, that they be not themselves confederates with their servants in evil-doing. Except only when I'm gaming, I don't care for any gain.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: At times, I've seen the Comedians, when acting, in this fashion repeat sayings in a wise manner, and be applauded for them, when they pointed out this prudent conduct to the public. sp.p: Go in-doors, don't be troublesome, moderate your tongue. I'm going to give you nothing, don't you deceive yourself.

p.#text: . Then I pray the Gods that whatever's in that wallet, whether it's gold, or whether silver, it may all become ashes.

This is the reason why we have bad servants. For this master, if he had combined with any servant, would have made both himself and the other guilty of a theft. sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: And is she to marry me?

sp.p: So I suspect.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: What then do you reckon?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: What you ask me, I reckon.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: Tell me then how much do you reckon it at?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: What I, I reckon----

note.#text: :  "At sume quidem," though not given by Fleckeisen, has been here adopted as the reading. "Censeo" seems to mean "to reckon up," as well as "to think." Salmasius and Gronovius suggest, and with fair reason, that he means jocularly to say, "Don't be always reckoning, but cast up and carry over."

p.#text: Then really, do carry over. Don't be always making a reckoning.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: So I reckon.

p.#text: What if I run?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: So I reckon.

p.#text: Or rather gently, this way?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: So I reckon.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: Ought I to salute her as well when I arrive?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: So I reckon.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: Her father too?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: So I reckon.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: After that, her mother?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: So I reckon.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: And what after that? When I arrive, should I also embrace her father?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: So I don't reckon.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: Well, her mother?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: So I don't reckon.

sp.speaker: PLESIDIPPUS
sp.p: Well, her own self?

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: So I don't reckon.

note.#text: :  "Dilectum dimisit." This expression is explained by some Commentators as alluding to the enlisting of soldiers, to which the word "censeo" was applicable. The play on the word "censeo" throughout this Scene is enwrapt in great obscurity.

p.#text: Confusion, he has closed his reckoning; now when I wish him, he doesn't reckon.

sp.speaker: TRACHALIO
sp.p: You are not in your senses; follow me.

p.stage: They go into the cottage of DMONES.
p.#text: Conduct me, my patron, where you please.

div2.stage: Enter LABRAX, at a distance.

note.#text: :  "Recuperatores." These were also called "judices selecti," and were "commissioned judges" appointed by the Prtors at  for the purpose of trying causes relative to property in dispute between parties. See the Bacchides, l. 270.

p.#text: . What other mortal being is there living this day more wretched than myself, whom before the commissioned judges Plesidippus has just now cast? Palstra has just been taken from me by award. I'm ruined outright. But I do believe that Procurers were procreated for mere sport; so much do all persons make sport if any misfortune befalls a Procurer. Now I'll go look here, in the Temple of Venus, for that other female, that her at least I may take away, the only portion of my property that remains.

div2.stage: Enter GRIPUS, from the cottage of DMONES, with a spit in his hand.

p.#text: . By the powers, you shall never this day at nightfall behold Gripus alive, unless the wallet is restored to me.
. I'm ready to die; when I hear mentior made anywhere of a wallet, I'm thumped, as it were with a stake, upon the breast.
. That scoundrel is free; I, the person that held the net in the sea, and drew up the wallet, to him you refuse to give anything.
. O ye immortal Gods! by his talk this person has made me prick up my ears.

. By my troth, in letters a cubit long, I'll immediately post it up in every quarter, "If any person has lost a wallet with plenty of gold and silver, let him come to Gripus." You shan't keep it as you are wishing.

stage: Some one calls GRIPUS, from within.
p.#text: . I' faith, this person knows, as I think, who has got the wallet. This person must be accosted by me; ye Gods, aid me, I do entreat you.

p.stage: He rubs away at the spit.

note.#text: :  He alludes to the rust which has eaten into the spit and worn it away.

p.#text: Why are you calling me back in-doors?  I want to clean this here before the door. But surely this, i' faith, has been made of rust, and not of iron; so that the more I rub it, it becomes quite red and more slender. Why surely this spit has been drugged; it does waste away so in my hands.
. Save you, young man.

note.#text: :  Madame Dacier suggests that Labrax has had his hair cut off in consequence of having escaped from shipwreck, which, indeed, was often done during the continuance of a storm by those at sea.

p.#text: May the Gods prosper you with your shorn pate.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: What's going on?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: A spit being cleaned.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: How do you do?

note.#text: :  He plays upon the resemblance of the words "medicus" and "mendicus." To give effect to the pun, we have, with , coined the word "medicant," in the sense of "doctor" or "physician."

p.#text: What are you? Prithee, are you a medicant?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: No, i' faith, I am more than a medicant by one letter.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Then you are a "mendicant."

note.#text: :  "Tetigisti acu." Literally, "you've hit it with the point"--that is, "exactly."

p.#text: You've hit it to a nicety.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Your appearance seems suitable to it. But what's the matter with you?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Troth, this last night I was shipwrecked at sea the vessel was cast away, and to my misfortune I lost there everything that I had.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: What did you lose?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: A wallet with plenty of gold and silver.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Do you at all remember what there was in the wallet which was lost?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: What matters for us now to be talking of it, if, in spite of it, it's lost?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: What if I know who has found it? I wish to learn from you the tokens.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Eight hundred golden pieces were there in a purse, besides a hundred Philippean min in a wash-leather bag apart.

p.#text: . Troth, it is a noble prize; I shall be getting a handsome reward. The Gods show respect to mortals; therefore I shall come off bounteously rewarded. No doubt, it is this man's wallet.  Do you proceed to relate the rest.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: A large talent of silver of full weight was in a purse, besides a bowl, a goblet, a beaker, a boat, and a cup.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Astonishing! you really did have some splendid riches.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: A shocking expression is that, and a most abominable one. "You did have, and now have not."

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: What would you be ready to give to one who should find these out for you, and give you information? Say, speedily and at once.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Three hundred didrachms.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Rubbish.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Four hundred.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Old thrums.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Five hundred.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: A rotten nut.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Six hundred.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: You are prating about mere tiny weevils.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: I'll give seven hundred.

note.#text: :  He is supposed here to allude to the act of drawing the breath into the mouth with the teeth half closed, which produces a sensation of coolness; meaning, that he doesn't speak out and offer with boldness.

p.#text: Your mouth is hot, you are cooling it just now.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: I'll give a thousand didrachms.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: You are dreaming.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: I add no more; be off with you.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Hear me then; if, i' faith, I should be off from here, I shan't be here.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Would you like a hundred as well as the thousand?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: You are asleep.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Say how much you ask.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: That you mayn't be adding anything against your inclination, a great talent; it's not possible for three obols to be bated thence; then do you say either "yes" or "no" at once.

p.#text: . What's to be done here? It's a matter of necessity, I see:  the talent shall be paid.
. Just step this way; I wish Venus here to put the question to you.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Whatever you please, that command me.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Touch this altar of Venus.

p.#text: . I am touching it.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: By Venus here must you swear to me.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: What must I swear?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: What I shall bid you.

note.#text: :  He says this to himself, meaning that he has a sufficient stock of perjury at home, without going to another person for it. See l. 558.

p.#text: Dictate in words just as you like.  What I've got at home, I shall never beg of any one else.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Take hold of this altar.

p.#text: . I am taking hold of it.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Swear that you will pay me the money on that same day on which you shall gain possession of the wallet.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Be it so.

p.stage: speaking, while LABRAX repeats after him
p.#text: . Venus of Cyrene, I invoke thee as my witness, if I shall find that wallet which I lost in the ship, safe with the gold and silver, and it shall come into my possession----

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: "Then to this Gripus do I promise;" say so and place your hand upon me.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Then to this Gripus do I promise, Venus, do thou hear me----

p.#text: . "That I will forthwith give him a great talent of silver."
If you defraud me, say, may Venus utterly destroy your body, and your existence in your calling.  As it is, do you have this for yourself, when you've once taken the oath.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: If, Venus, I shall do anything amiss against this oath, I supplicate thee that all Procurers may henceforth be wretched.

p.#text: . As it is, it shall be so, even if you do keep your oath. Do you wait here; --I'll at once make the old gentleman come out; do you forthwith demand of him that wallet.

. If ever so much he shall restore to me this wallet, I'm not this day indebted to him three obols even. It's according to my own intention what my tongue swears.  But I'll hold my peace; see, here he's coming out, and bringing the old man.

div2.stage: Enter GRIPUS, followed by DMONES, with the wallet.

p.#text: Follow this way. Where is this Procurer? Hark you , see now; this person  has got your wallet.

I have got it, and I confess that it is in my possession; and if it's yours, you may have it. Everything, just as each particular was in it, shall in like manner be given safe to you.  Take it, if it's yours.
Immortal Gods, it is mine.  Welcome, dear wallet.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: Is it yours?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Do you ask the question? If indeed, i' faith, it were in Jove's possession, still it is my own.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: Everything in it is safe; there has only been one casket taken out of it, with some trinkets, by means of which this day I have found my daughter.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: What person?

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: Palstra, who was your property, she has been discovered to be my own daughter.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: By my troth, it has happily turned out so; since this matter has happened so fortunately for you according to your wishes, I'm rejoiced.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: In that I don't readily believe you.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Aye, by my faith, that you may be sure that I'm rejoiced, you shan't give me three obols for her; I excuse you.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: I' faith, you are acting kindly.

p.#text: No, troth; it's really yourself, indeed, that's doing so.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Hark you, you've got the wallet now.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: I have got it.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Make haste.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Make haste about what?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: To pay me the money.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: By my troth, I'll neither give you anything nor do I owe you anything.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: What mode of proceeding is this? Don't you owe it me?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Troth, not I indeed.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Didn't you promise it me upon your oath?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: I did take an oath, and now I'll take an oath, if it is in any way my own pleasure; oaths were invented for preserving property, not for losing it.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Give me, will you, a great talent of silver, you most perjured fellow.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: Gripus, what talent is it you are asking him for?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: He promised it me on oath.

note.#text: :  The meaning of this passage is doubtful, but he seems to ask Dmones, "Are you the Priest of Venus, in whose presence I took the oath?" It was probably the duty of the priesthood to take cognizance of cases of perjury.

p.#text: I chose to swear;  are you the priest as to my perjury?
. For what reason did he promise you the money?

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: If I restored this wallet into his hands, he swore that he would give me a great talent of silver.

note.#text: :  By the Ltorian law (which is also referred to in the Notes to the Pseudolus), persons under the age of five-and- twenty were deemed minors, and free from all pecuniary obligations. As usual, in this allusion Plautus consults the usages of his Audience, and not of the place where the Scene is laid. Labrax is ready to say or swear anything; and Madame Dacier justly remarks, that it is amusing enough that he should call himself not five-and-twenty, when he is described, in the Second Scene of the First Act, as a person having grey hair. Gripus being a slave, could not try the question at law with Labrax.

p.#text: Find me a person with whom I may go to the judge, to decide whether you did not make the bargain with wicked fraudulence, and whether I am yet five-and-twenty years old.
. Go to the judge with him.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: No; I must have some other person.

p.#text: . Then I shan't allow you to take it away from him, unless I shall have found him guilty. Did you promise him the money?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: I confess it.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: What you promised my slave must needs be my own. Don't you be supposing, Procurer, that you are to be using your pimping honesty here. That can't be.

p.#text: . Did you fancy now that you had got hold of a person whom you might cheat? It must be paid down here , good silver coin; I shall, at once, pay it to him , so that he may give me my liberty.
Inasmuch, therefore, as I have acted courteously towards you, and by my means these things  have been saved for you----

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: I' faith, by my means, rather; don't say by yours.

p.#text: . If you are prudent you'll hold your tongue.  Then it befits you in a like courteous manner kindly to return the obligation to myself, who so well merit the same.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: You are pleading, of course, for my right?

p.#text: . It would be a wonder if I didn't, at a loss to myself, ask you to forego your right.
. I'm all right; the Procurer's giving way; my freedom is at hand.
. He found this wallet; he is my slave. I therefore have preserved this for you, together with a large sum of money.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: I return you thanks, and with regard to the talent that I promised on oath to him, there's no reason that you shouldn't receive it.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Hark you, give it me then, if you are wise.

p.#text: . Will you hold your tongue, or not?

note.#text: :  By this he means the wallet and its contents.

p.#text: You pretend to be acting on my side: I tell you * * * * * * by my troth, you shan't do me out of that, if I did lose the other booty.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: You shall have a beating if you add a single word.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Troth now, do you kill me even; I'll never be silent on any terms, unless my mouth is shut with the talent.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: For yourself, in fact, is he using his exertions; do hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: Step this way, Procurer.

p.#text: Very well.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Proceed openly; I don't want any whisperings or mumblings to be going on.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: Tell me, at what price did you buy that other young woman, Ampelisca?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: I paid down a thousand didrachms.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: Should you like me to make you a handsome offer?

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: I should like it much.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: I'll divide the talent.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: You act fairly.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: For that other woman Ampelisca, that she may be free, take you one half, and give the other half to him.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: By all means.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: For that half I'll give his freedom to Gripus, by means of whom you found your wallet, and I my daughter.

p.#text: You act fairly; I return you many thanks.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: How soon then is the money to be returned to me?

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: The money's paid, Gripus; I've got it.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: You, faith; but I had rather it were myself.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: I' faith, there's nothing for you here, so don't you be expecting it. I wish you to release him from his oath.

note.#text: :  Thorntor calls this "a sorry witticism;" but Madame Dacier and other Commentators discover great humour in it It certainly is amusing for its absurdity.

p.#text: Troth, I'm undone; if I don't hang myself, I'm utterly done for.  I' faith, after this day you certainly shall never be cheating me again.

sp.speaker: DM.
sp.p: Dine here to-day, Procurer.

sp.speaker: LABRAX
sp.p: Be it so; the proposal is to my taste.

stage: He comes forward and addresses the AUDIENCE.
p.#text: Do you both follow me in-doors.  Spectators, I would invite you to dinner as well, were it not that I'm going to give nothing, and that there is no good cheer at all at home; and if, too, I didn't believe that you are invited to dinner elsewhere. But if you shall be willing to give hearty applause to this Play, do you all come to make merry at my house some sixteen years hence. Do you  both dine here with me to-day.

sp.speaker: GRIPUS
sp.p: Be it so.

note.#text: This Play, though pronounced to be one of the best of this author, does not conclude satisfactorily. We are not told what becomes of Ampelisca, or of Trachalio, who aspires to the honor of her hand. The sturdy Sceparnio we lose sight of too early; and Dmones loses all claim to our estimation, by inviting such an infamous villain as Labrax to take a place at his table, who certainly, according to the usual rules of dramatic retribution, richly deserves to lose his wallet and its contents

p.#text: Now give us your applause.
